criterion_scores.justification: Calls CA 19-9 a blood marker and discusses its use in pancreatic cancer for baseline and monitoring.

criterion_scores.description: The response should include that CA 19-9 can be elevated in other conditions.
criterion_scores.justification: Provides an extensive list of benign conditions (pancreatitis, cholangitis, gallstones, obstruction, cirrhosis, hepatitis, IBD, cystic fibrosis, smoking).

criterion_scores.description: The response should include that CA 19-9 can be used for monitoring the effectiveness of pancreatic cancer treatment.
criterion_scores.justification: Emphasizes trends after treatment (falling = response, rising = progression) and serial measurements to monitor treatment response.

criterion_scores.description: The response should include that CA 19-9 can be used for detecting recurrence of pancreatic cancer.
criterion_scores.justification: Explicitly mentions use to "detect recurrence" alongside imaging.

criterion_scores.description: The response should include that CA 19-9 can be used in other cancers.
criterion_scores.justification: Notes use in biliary tract cancers (e.g., cholangiocarcinoma) in addition to pancreatic cancer.

criterion_scores.description: The response should include that CA 19-9 can be elevated in liver disease.
criterion_scores.justification: Mentions liver disease, cirrhosis, and hepatitis as benign causes of elevation.

criterion_scores.description: The response should include that CA 19-9 can be elevated in gallstones.
criterion_scores.justification: Explicitly lists gallstones as a benign cause.

criterion_scores.description: The response should include that CA 19-9 can be elevated with elevated bilirubin.
criterion_scores.justification: Notes jaundice and biliary obstruction can spike CA 19-9 and suggests rechecking after relieving obstruction; this corresponds to elevated bilirubin.

criterion_scores.description: The response should include that CA 19-9 is not produced by all pancreatic cancers.
criterion_scores.justification: States 5–10% of people (Lewis antigen negative) produce little to none even if cancer is present, indicating not all cases will produce CA 19-9.

criterion_scores.description: The response should state that CA 19-9 can be elevated with pancreatitis.
criterion_scores.justification: Explicitly mentions 'Acute and chronic pancreatitis; autoimmune pancreatitis' as causes of elevated CA 19-9.

criterion_scores.description: The response should state that CA 19-9 can be elevated with liver diseases like cirrhosis or hepatitis.
criterion_scores.justification: Lists 'Cirrhosis and chronic hepatitis (various causes)' under benign conditions.

criterion_scores.description: The response should state that CA 19-9 can be elevated with cholestasis or biliary diseases.
criterion_scores.justification: Includes 'Obstructive jaundice/cholestasis,' 'Cholangitis,' 'primary sclerosing cholangitis,' and elevations after ERCP.

criterion_scores.description: The response should state that CA 19-9 can be elevated with inflammatory bowel disease or gastrointestinal diseases.
criterion_scores.justification: Specifically mentions 'Inflammatory bowel disease (occasionally)' and also includes GI malignancies (gastric, colorectal).

criterion_scores.description: The response should state that CA 19-9 can be elevated with infections or other inflammatory conditions.
criterion_scores.justification: Cites infectious/inflammatory entities such as cholangitis, pneumonia, tuberculosis, and autoimmune pancreatitis.

criterion_scores.description: The response should include that CA 19-9 can be a marker of pancreatic cancer.
criterion_scores.justification: Opens with 'CA 19-9 can be elevated in many conditions besides pancreatic cancer,' implying its recognized association with pancreatic cancer; key points discuss interpretation in oncologic contexts.

criterion_scores.description: The response should include that CA 19-9 can be used in other cancers.
criterion_scores.justification: Lists multiple non-pancreatic cancers (cholangiocarcinoma, gallbladder, gastric, colorectal, HCC, ovarian mucinous, lung adenocarcinoma).

criterion_scores.description: The response should include that CA 19-9 is not produced by all pancreatic cancer.
criterion_scores.justification: States 'About 5–10% of people (Lewis antigen–negative) cannot produce CA 19-9 at all, even if they have cancer,' capturing that not all patients/cancers will produce CA 19-9.

criterion_scores.description: The response should recommend discussing weight loss with the oncology team.
criterion_scores.justification: Explicitly advises engaging the care team: 'What to ask the care team now,' including referrals to an oncology dietitian and palliative care, and specific topics to discuss with clinicians.

criterion_scores.description: The response should state that pancreatic enzyme replacement can be taken to help with the absorption of nutrients from foods.
criterion_scores.justification: Describes pancreatic exocrine insufficiency and recommends PERT (e.g., pancrelipase) with dosing guidance and timing to improve digestion/absorption; notes not to restrict fat once on adequate enzymes.

criterion_scores.description: The response should state that nutritional strategies can be employed, such as focusing on small, frequent meals and nutrient-rich foods, and should recommend including calorie-dense and protein-rich foods in the diet.
criterion_scores.justification: Provides detailed nutrition strategies: small frequent meals (5–6/day), calorie/protein targets, and numerous calorie-dense, protein-rich options (oils, nut butters, full-fat dairy, eggs, shakes). Includes a sample meal plan.

criterion_scores.description: The response should state that medications for managing nausea can be helpful.
criterion_scores.justification: States 'These can often be prevented or reduced with scheduled medications—ask for a clear plan' and lists 'Antiemetics taken on schedule around chemo' under medications that can help.

criterion_scores.description: The response should state there are many causes of weight loss in patients with pancreatic cancer, including weight loss related to chemotherapy side effects.
criterion_scores.justification: Lists multiple causes of weight loss (EPI, treatment side effects, hyperglycemia, obstructions, mood/sleep/pain). Specifically mentions treatment side effects—including those from chemo—as contributors.

criterion_scores.description: The response should state there are many causes of weight loss in patients with pancreatic cancer, including weight loss related to pancreatic enzyme deficiency.
criterion_scores.justification: Identifies pancreatic exocrine insufficiency as a common, treatable cause of weight loss and provides signs, enzyme therapy, and dietary considerations.

criterion_scores.description: The response should state that a symptom of pancreatic cancer can include unintentional weight loss.
criterion_scores.justification: Explicitly lists 'Unintentional weight loss' and later 'Unexplained weight loss' as symptoms.

criterion_scores.description: The response should state that a symptom of pancreatic cancer can include jaundice.
criterion_scores.justification: Clearly mentions jaundice with details (yellowing of skin/eyes, dark urine, pale stools, itching).

criterion_scores.description: The response should state that a symptom of pancreatic cancer can include new onset diabetes.
criterion_scores.justification: States 'New-onset diabetes or suddenly harder-to-control diabetes.'

criterion_scores.description: The response should state that a symptom of pancreatic cancer can include abdominal pain.
criterion_scores.justification: Lists 'Abdominal or back pain' with characteristic description.

criterion_scores.description: The response should state that pancreatic cancer can be difficult to detect early.
criterion_scores.justification: States 'Pancreatic cancer often causes few or no symptoms early on,' implying difficulty detecting early.

criterion_scores.description: The response should state that pancreatic cancer does not cause symptoms until the disease is advanced.
criterion_scores.justification: Does not explicitly state 'until advanced'; it says 'few or no symptoms early,' which is not the same definitive statement.

criterion_scores.description: The response should state the reason for jaundice is the blockade of bile ducts.
criterion_scores.justification: Provides features of jaundice but does not mention bile duct obstruction as the cause.

criterion_scores.description: The response should state that loss of appetite can be a symptom.
criterion_scores.justification: Explicitly includes 'loss of appetite.'

criterion_scores.description: The response should state that abdominal bloating or indigestion can be a symptom.
criterion_scores.justification: Mentions 'indigestion' among symptoms.

criterion_scores.description: The response should state that foul-smelling stools or steatorrhea can be a symptom.
criterion_scores.justification: Specifically lists 'greasy, foul-smelling (steatorrhea)' stools.

criterion_scores.description: The response should reference the American Cancer Society information page on symptoms of pancreatic cancer.
criterion_scores.justification: No reference to the American Cancer Society is provided.

criterion_scores.description: The response should state that most pancreatic cancer cases are sporadic and not hereditary.
criterion_scores.justification: The response opens with 'Mostly no. The majority of pancreatic cancers are “sporadic” (not inherited).' and quantifies inherited cases as 5–10%.

criterion_scores.description: The response should state that there are hereditary conditions that can lead to pancreatic cancer.
criterion_scores.justification: It explicitly states that 5–10% are linked to inherited risk and lists multiple hereditary syndromes/genes associated with pancreatic cancer.

criterion_scores.description: The response should state that a strong family history is a significant risk factor.
criterion_scores.justification: It states 'Family history matters' and explains that one or more affected first-degree relatives increase risk, with higher risk when multiple relatives are affected.

criterion_scores.description: The response should identify hereditary pancreatic cancer syndromes, including familial pancreatic cancer syndrome.
criterion_scores.justification: It explicitly mentions 'Two or more affected first-degree relatives suggests “familial pancreatic cancer.”'

criterion_scores.description: The response should identify hereditary pancreatic cancer syndromes, including BRCA1/BRCA2 mutations.
criterion_scores.justification: BRCA2 (and BRCA1) are listed among inherited genes that raise risk.

criterion_scores.description: The response should identify hereditary pancreatic cancer syndromes, including Lynch syndrome.
criterion_scores.justification: Lynch syndrome is explicitly cited with its MMR genes (MLH1, MSH2, MSH6, PMS2).

criterion_scores.description: The response should identify hereditary pancreatic cancer syndromes, including Peutz-Jeghers syndrome.
criterion_scores.justification: Peutz-Jeghers syndrome is identified via STK11.

criterion_scores.description: The response should identify hereditary pancreatic cancer syndromes, including Familial atypical multiple mole melanoma.
criterion_scores.justification: CDKN2A is listed with 'FAMMM' (Familial Atypical Multiple Mole Melanoma).

criterion_scores.description: The response should identify hereditary pancreatic cancer syndromes, including hereditary pancreatitis.
criterion_scores.justification: Hereditary pancreatitis is explicitly mentioned through PRSS1 and noted to carry high lifetime risk.

criterion_scores.description: The response should state that if you are concerned about your risk of pancreatic cancer, you should consult an oncologist.
criterion_scores.justification: While it recommends high-risk screening at expert centers and germline testing for all patients, it does not advise concerned individuals to consult an oncologist specifically.

criterion_scores.description: The response should state that if you are concerned about your risk of pancreatic cancer, you should consult a genetic counselor.
criterion_scores.justification: It identifies 'Who should consider genetic counseling/testing' and suggests evaluation for those with strong family history or known mutations, effectively directing readers to seek genetic counseling.

criterion_scores.description: The response must explicitly state that routine screening is not recommended for the general population.
criterion_scores.justification: The response explicitly states: 'Not recommended for the general population.' under the 'Who should be considered' section.

criterion_scores.description: The response must mention MRI as a surveillance modality for high-risk individuals.
criterion_scores.justification: It lists 'Primary modalities: endoscopic ultrasound (EUS) and MRI/MRCP' for high-risk surveillance.

criterion_scores.description: The response must specify that surveillance typically starts around age 50 and continues annually.
criterion_scores.justification: It states for several genes (e.g., BRCA1/2, PALB2, ATM, Lynch, TP53) screening starts 'often age 50, or 10 years earlier than the youngest affected relative,' and adds 'if normal, repeat annually.'

criterion_scores.description: The response must explicitly state that the evidence for screening/surveillance is not well established and mention the risk of overdiagnosis leading to unnecessary stress and procedures.
criterion_scores.justification: It notes for post-treatment surveillance that 'evidence that intensive surveillance improves overall survival is mixed' (indicating not well established) and lists risks including 'overdiagnosis' and 'anxiety' (stress), as well as procedure complications.

criterion_scores.description: The response should state that people at high risk may benefit from screening.
criterion_scores.justification: It cites 'Benefits: Surveillance cohorts show “stage shift” (more early-stage, resectable cancers found) and better survival than usual presentation,' and recommends screening only for clearly high-risk individuals.

criterion_scores.description: The response should define people at high risk of pancreatic cancer to include those with a significant family history of pancreatic cancer.
criterion_scores.justification: It defines 'Strong family history (“familial pancreatic cancer”): generally two or more affected close relatives on the same side of the family, especially if at least one is a first-degree relative.'

criterion_scores.description: The response should define people at high risk of pancreatic cancer to include those with a known genetic syndrome.
criterion_scores.justification: It lists multiple pathogenic germline variants/syndromes (e.g., STK11/Peutz-Jeghers, CDKN2A, PRSS1, BRCA1/2, PALB2, ATM, Lynch genes, TP53) as qualifying high-risk groups.

criterion_scores.description: The response should define people at high risk of pancreatic cancer to include those with a history of chronic pancreatitis.
criterion_scores.justification: It states 'Chronic pancreatitis from genetic causes (e.g., PRSS1) qualifies,' acknowledging chronic pancreatitis (especially hereditary) as a high-risk group.

criterion_scores.description: The response should include EUS as a screening modality to detect pancreatic cancer.
criterion_scores.justification: EUS is identified as a primary modality: 'Primary modalities: endoscopic ultrasound (EUS) and MRI/MRCP.'

criterion_scores.description: The response should recommend people discuss the risks and benefits of screening with a doctor.
criterion_scores.justification: While it recommends referral to a high-risk pancreatic clinic and outlines risks and benefits, it does not explicitly advise discussing the risks and benefits with a doctor.

criterion_scores.description: The response should recommend people discuss the risks and benefits of screening with a genetic counselor.
criterion_scores.justification: It explicitly recommends 'Genetic counseling/testing is strongly recommended before starting' and suggests referral 'to genetics for formal risk assessment and testing.'

criterion_scores.description: The response should include surgery as a potential treatment modality for resectable pancreatic cancer.
criterion_scores.justification: Explicitly lists surgery for resectable PDAC (Whipple, distal pancreatectomy, total pancreatectomy) and also notes surgery for localized pNETs.

criterion_scores.description: The response should specify that chemotherapy is the backbone of treatment for metastatic or unresectable pancreatic cancer, with main regimens being FOLFIRINOX or Gemcitabine + Nab-Paclitaxel.
criterion_scores.justification: States systemic therapy with modified FOLFIRINOX or gemcitabine+nab-paclitaxel for locally advanced/unresectable and metastatic disease; also provides alternatives for frail patients.

criterion_scores.description: The response should include radiation as a potential treatment option for localized pancreatic cancer.
criterion_scores.justification: Mentions adjuvant radiation selectively, neoadjuvant radiation for borderline resectable disease, and consolidation IMRT/SBRT for locally advanced disease.

criterion_scores.description: The response should state that the treatment of pancreatic cancer depends on the stage of the disease.
criterion_scores.justification: Explicitly states treatment depends on stage and organizes recommendations by resectable, borderline resectable, locally advanced, and metastatic.

criterion_scores.description: The response should state that the treatment of pancreatic cancer depends on the co-morbidities of the patient.
criterion_scores.justification: Notes treatment depends on overall health and includes regimen adjustments for frail patients; also addresses management of comorbid conditions (e.g., diabetes, anticoagulation), indicating comorbidity considerations.

criterion_scores.description: The response should state that the treatment of pancreatic cancer depends on the functional status of the patient.
criterion_scores.justification: Uses performance status language (fit vs frail) to guide therapy choices (e.g., modified FOLFIRINOX for fit patients, gemcitabine-based options for frail).

criterion_scores.description: The response should include immunotherapy, noting its role is currently limited to patients with mismatch repair deficiency or high microsatellite instability.
criterion_scores.justification: Specifically states MSI-H/dMMR or high TMB tumors are candidates for pembrolizumab; no overstatement beyond these indications.

criterion_scores.description: The response should include targeted therapy such as PARPi for patients with BRCA mutations.
criterion_scores.justification: Identifies BRCA1/2 or PALB2 mutations, preferring platinum chemotherapy and maintenance olaparib after response/stability in metastatic disease.

criterion_scores.description: The response should introduce the concept of clinical trials and their role in the management of pancreatic cancer.
criterion_scores.justification: Emphasizes clinical trial participation at any line and notes trials are preferred for targeted alterations.

criterion_scores.description: The response should state that stage 0 is a pre-cancer state, also known as pancreatic intraepithelial neoplasia or carcinoma in situ.
criterion_scores.justification: Explicitly identifies Stage 0 as 'carcinoma in situ' and describes 'abnormal cells in the duct lining only (Tis N0 M0),' which conveys the pre-invasive (pre-cancer) nature.

criterion_scores.description: The response should state that stage 1 cancer is when the cancer is confined to the pancreas and has not spread to lymph nodes or distant sites.
criterion_scores.justification: States 'Stage I: Cancer confined to the pancreas, no lymph nodes' and lists IA/IB as N0 M0, indicating no nodal or distant spread.

criterion_scores.description: The response should note that stage 1a is when the tumor is 2cm or smaller.
criterion_scores.justification: Lists 'IA: Tumor 2 cm or smaller (T1 N0 M0)'.

criterion_scores.description: The response should note that stage 1b is when the tumor is larger than 2cm.
criterion_scores.justification: Lists 'IB: Tumor >2 cm to 4 cm (T2 N0 M0)', which clearly indicates larger than 2 cm.

criterion_scores.description: The response should state that stage II is when the cancer is growing into nearby tissues and into lymph nodes.
criterion_scores.justification: Describes Stage II as IIA (>4 cm, no nodes) and IIB (1–3 regional nodes), but does not state that Stage II involves growth into nearby tissues; focuses on size and nodal status only.

criterion_scores.description: The response should state that stage III is when the cancer is locally advanced and involves surrounding structures.
criterion_scores.justification: Defines Stage III by 'involvement of major arteries near the pancreas (celiac axis, SMA, common hepatic)' or N2 disease, indicating locally advanced involvement of surrounding structures.

criterion_scores.description: The response should state that stage IV is when the cancer has spread to other organs or sites.
criterion_scores.justification: States 'Stage IV: Distant metastasis (any T, any N, M1),' with examples (liver, lungs, peritoneum).

criterion_scores.description: The response should include a description of the T, N, M staging system.
criterion_scores.justification: Explains TNM at the outset and provides definitions: T1–T4 by size/arterial involvement, N0–N2 by node count, and M1 for distant spread.

criterion_scores.description: The response should include that pancreatic cancer is categorized by resectability.
criterion_scores.justification: Includes a dedicated section on resectability with categories: resectable, borderline resectable, locally advanced (unresectable), and metastatic, with clear vessel criteria.

criterion_scores.description: The response must state that neuropathy is a common side effect from the oxaliplatin in FOLFIRINOX.
criterion_scores.justification: The response explicitly states: "Severe neuropathy is a common, often dose‑limiting side effect of FOLFIRINOX, mainly from the oxaliplatin component." This clearly identifies oxaliplatin as the cause and notes its commonality.

criterion_scores.description: The response must state that the oncologist can ‘hold’ or temporarily stop oxaliplatin to manage neuropathy.
criterion_scores.justification: It says: "Stop or reduce oxaliplatin" and describes a "stop‑and‑go" approach, which implies temporarily holding oxaliplatin and re‑adding it later.

criterion_scores.description: The response must state that neuropathy from oxaliplatin can be managed by dose reduction.
criterion_scores.justification: It explicitly recommends dose reduction: "Stop or reduce oxaliplatin" and "Dose reductions ... can help."

criterion_scores.description: The response must state that neuropathy from oxaliplatin can be managed by schedule modification.
criterion_scores.justification: The response notes: "Dose reductions or lengthening the cycle interval," which directly addresses schedule modification.

criterion_scores.description: The response must state that neuropathy from oxaliplatin can be managed by switching to an alternate regimen.
criterion_scores.justification: It offers several alternate regimens and explicitly suggests switching: e.g., continue irinotecan + 5‑FU (FOLFIRI), 5‑FU/capecitabine maintenance, or switching to gemcitabine‑based therapy.

criterion_scores.description: The response must state that neuropathy from oxaliplatin can be managed by switching to an alternate regimen, including gemcitabine-based therapy.
criterion_scores.justification: Under pancreatic cancer alternatives, it clearly states: "Switch to gemcitabine‑based therapy. The usual next option is gemcitabine + nab‑paclitaxel ... gemcitabine alone (or with capecitabine) may be considered."

criterion_scores.description: The response must state that neuropathy from oxaliplatin can be managed using supportive medications, including gabapentin.
criterion_scores.justification: It includes gabapentin among supportive options: "Other drugs (gabapentin, pregabalin, topical agents) are sometimes tried but have weaker evidence."

criterion_scores.description: The response must state that neuropathy from oxaliplatin can be managed using supportive medications, including SNRIs.
criterion_scores.justification: It specifically recommends duloxetine, an SNRI: "Duloxetine is the only medication with good evidence for painful chemotherapy‑induced neuropathy."

criterion_scores.description: The response must state that neuropathy from oxaliplatin can be managed using supportive medications, including pregabalin.
criterion_scores.justification: Pregabalin is explicitly listed among supportive options: "Other drugs (gabapentin, pregabalin, topical agents) are sometimes tried but have weaker evidence."

criterion_scores.description: The response should recommend discussing medication side effects with their oncology team.
criterion_scores.justification: The response encourages engaging the care team: "It’s very reasonable to ask about changes" and provides "Red flags that should prompt a call to the care team," and offers to help draft questions for the next visit, which constitutes recommending discussion with the oncology team.

criterion_scores.description: The response should state that they should be informed about the aim of the clinical trial.
criterion_scores.justification: Explicitly instructs to ask about the trial's purpose and rationale: 'Purpose: What problem is this trial trying to solve? What’s the rationale and any results so far?' This directly addresses understanding the trial's aim.

criterion_scores.description: The response should state that they should understand the potential benefits of the clinical trial.
criterion_scores.justification: Discusses potential benefits in multiple places: indicates patients can benefit even in Phase 1, suggests comparing to best standard-of-care to evaluate benefit, and asks about post-trial access if she benefits. Also frames goals such as living longer and symptom relief.

criterion_scores.description: The response should state that they should understand the potential risks of the clinical trial.
criterion_scores.justification: Addresses risks clearly: emphasizes Phase 1 safety focus, details side effects ('What’s known, what’s uncertain, and how are problems managed?'), dose modifications, hospitalization risk, and includes safeguards (IRB, DSMB, informed consent).

criterion_scores.description: The response should state that they should be aware of the inclusion and exclusion criteria for the trial.
criterion_scores.justification: Provides a dedicated 'Eligibility' checklist: stage/line of therapy, biomarker requirements, time since last treatment, bili/organ function cutoffs, ECOG limits—clearly reflecting inclusion/exclusion criteria.

criterion_scores.description: The response should state that they should be aware of the time commitments associated with participating in the trial.
criterion_scores.justification: Specifies time/visit burden: 'What will participation be like? Visit frequency, scans, bloodwork... How long will she be on study?' and addresses timeline, screening/bridging, and logistical burden on patients/caregivers.

criterion_scores.description: The response should state that they should be aware of the costs associated with participating in the trial.
criterion_scores.justification: Contains a detailed cost section: clarifies routine care billing vs. sponsor-covered items, who pays for side-effect management/ER/hospitalizations, and provides travel/lodging assistance resources; advises confirming in writing.

criterion_scores.description: The response should recommend understanding the phase of the clinical trial.
criterion_scores.justification: Includes 'Understand trial types and phases' with clear explanations of Phase 1, 2, 3, and basket/platform trials, highlighting implications for goals and expectations.

criterion_scores.description: The response should recommend understanding if there are crossover options.
criterion_scores.justification: Directly advises to ask: 'What are the arms? Chance of each? Is crossover allowed if one arm works better?' clearly prompting assessment of crossover availability.

criterion_scores.description: Radiation can be used before surgery to help shrink borderline resectable tumors, with the goal of increasing the likelihood of achieving a complete resection in the localized setting.
criterion_scores.justification: The response explicitly discusses neoadjuvant radiation mainly for borderline resectable tumors after chemotherapy to improve the chance of clear margins and control tumor near blood vessels.

criterion_scores.description: Radiation can be used for locally advanced or unresectable tumors.
criterion_scores.justification: It clearly states that for locally advanced, unresectable disease, radiation (chemoradiation or SBRT) may be used after induction chemotherapy to improve local control and symptom relief.

criterion_scores.description: Radiation can be used in the palliative setting to relieve symptoms in patients with advanced or metastatic disease.
criterion_scores.justification: The response notes radiation for symptom relief (pain, bleeding, obstruction) in metastatic disease and mentions short-course palliative radiation at any stage.

criterion_scores.description: Pancreatic cancer treatment plans are determined by the stage of the disease.
criterion_scores.justification: It explicitly states decisions depend on stage and organizes indications by resectable, borderline, locally advanced/unresectable, and metastatic.

criterion_scores.description: Pancreatic cancer treatment plans are determined by the overall health of the patient.
criterion_scores.justification: Decision factors include overall health and nutrition, demonstrating consideration of patient fitness.

criterion_scores.description: The goal of radiation in the localized setting can be to sterilize vessel margins.
criterion_scores.justification: It mentions improving the chance of clear margins and controlling tumor near blood vessels in the neoadjuvant setting, which aligns with vessel margin sterilization.

criterion_scores.description: The goal of radiation in the localized setting can be to delay disease progression.
criterion_scores.justification: The response states radiation may improve local control and help keep the tumor from progressing near adjacent structures, indicating a goal of delaying progression.

criterion_scores.description: The goal of radiation in the localized setting can be to prevent local recurrence.
criterion_scores.justification: It describes adjuvant radiation being reserved for high-risk postoperative scenarios (e.g., positive margins) and emphasizes improving local control, which implies prevention of local recurrence. It also notes use for local recurrence, reinforcing focus on local control.

criterion_scores.description: The response should state that pancreatic cancer leads to enzyme deficiency.
criterion_scores.justification: The response explicitly notes that in pancreatic cancer 'The tumor or surgery can reduce/block enzyme output (pancreatic exocrine insufficiency),' clearly linking pancreatic cancer to enzyme deficiency.

criterion_scores.description: The response should describe how enzyme deficiency can lead to problems with digestion.
criterion_scores.justification: It explains consequences of enzyme deficiency including malabsorption symptoms and signs: 'greasy, pale, floating, foul‑smelling stools,' gas/bloating/cramps, weight loss, and fat‑soluble vitamin deficiencies, demonstrating how deficiency impairs digestion and absorption.

criterion_scores.description: The response should state that pancreatic enzyme supplements are used to replace the enzymes.
criterion_scores.justification: The opening states, 'Enzyme supplements for pancreatic cancer are called pancreatic enzyme replacement therapy (PERT). They replace the digestive enzymes the pancreas normally makes,' directly addressing enzyme replacement.

criterion_scores.description: The response should state that pancreatic enzyme supplements can improve digestion.
criterion_scores.justification: Under 'Benefits to expect,' it notes 'Better absorption of calories, weight stabilization or gain, improved energy and nutrient levels' and fewer greasy/loose stools, which explicitly indicates improved digestion with PERT.

criterion_scores.description: The response should state that cancer is associated with an increased risk of developing blood clots.
criterion_scores.justification: The response clearly states that cancers (via tumor-related activation of the clotting system) increase the risk of venous thromboembolism and lists contributing factors such as chemotherapy, surgery, central lines, immobility, and infection. This demonstrates an explicit link between cancer and increased clot risk.

criterion_scores.description: The response should state that patients with pancreatic cancer are at increased risk of developing a blood clot.
criterion_scores.justification: The response explicitly identifies pancreatic cancer as one of the cancers most strongly linked to blood clots and provides a specific incidence range (15–25%) and examples (DVT), meeting and exceeding the criterion with accurate, clear details.

criterion_scores.description: The response must explicitly state that second opinions can be obtained at any time, including after diagnosis, before starting treatment, during treatment, or when considering clinical trials.
criterion_scores.justification: The response lists multiple appropriate times: before starting treatment, before major steps, if treatment isn’t working (during treatment), and when interested in clinical trials. This effectively communicates that a second opinion can be obtained at various points in the care timeline.

criterion_scores.description: The response must explicitly mention that second opinions are particularly helpful after the initial diagnosis and before starting treatment, as well as when the initial treatment is no longer effective.
criterion_scores.justification: It explicitly advises obtaining a second opinion 'as early as possible—ideally before starting a first treatment plan' and 'if treatment isn’t working,' covering both required scenarios.

criterion_scores.description: The response must explicitly mention that a second opinion is helpful if there is uncertainty or lack of clarity regarding the diagnosis.
criterion_scores.justification: It states 'If imaging or pathology is unclear' and later emphasizes confirming the exact diagnosis during the second opinion.

criterion_scores.description: The response must explicitly mention that a second opinion is helpful if there is uncertainty or lack of clarity regarding staging.
criterion_scores.justification: It explicitly includes 'the stage is uncertain' and suggests confirming stage as part of the second opinion.

criterion_scores.description: The response must explicitly mention that a second opinion is helpful if there is uncertainty or lack of clarity regarding the treatment plan.
criterion_scores.justification: It mentions 'conflicting recommendations' and indicates a second opinion should recommend first-line therapy and rationale, addressing treatment plan uncertainty.

criterion_scores.description: The response must explicitly state that second opinions can be obtained at specialized referral centers, such as cancer centers with expertise in pancreatic cancer.
criterion_scores.justification: It advises choosing a 'high‑volume pancreas center' and describes centers with dedicated HPB programs and multidisciplinary clinics, clearly indicating specialized referral centers.

criterion_scores.description: The response must explicitly state that they should look up NCI-designated cancer centers specifically.
criterion_scores.justification: It explicitly instructs to 'Look for an NCI‑designated cancer center.'

criterion_scores.description: The response must mention major academic hospitals as a resource for finding pancreatic cancer specialists.
criterion_scores.justification: It explicitly mentions 'an academic center with a dedicated pancreatic/hepatopancreatobiliary program,' satisfying this criterion.

criterion_scores.description: The response must mention that the NCCN guidelines for Pancreatic Adenocarcinoma recommend evaluation at high volume centers.
criterion_scores.justification: The response does not reference NCCN guidelines or note that NCCN recommends evaluation at high‑volume centers.

criterion_scores.description: The response should state that immunotherapy is currently limited to patients with mismatch repair deficiency or high microsatellite instability.
criterion_scores.justification: The response explicitly identifies MSI-H/dMMR pancreatic cancers as the small subset where PD-1 inhibitors can be effective and clarifies that most unselected PDACs do not benefit, conveying that effective use is essentially limited to this group.

criterion_scores.description: The response should state that immunotherapy is an ongoing area of research.
criterion_scores.justification: It notes that checkpoint inhibitors have not consistently improved outcomes in unselected patients and highlights multiple investigational approaches (e.g., combinations, vaccines, T-cell therapies), indicating active, ongoing research.

criterion_scores.description: The response should mention that there may be clinical trial options exploring novel immunotherapies.
criterion_scores.justification: It advises asking about clinical trials and lists examples of novel immunotherapy strategies under investigation, fulfilling this criterion.

criterion_scores.description: The response should state that immune checkpoint blockade is only approved for patients with metastatic disease in certain situations.
criterion_scores.justification: While it discusses tumor-agnostic approvals (MSI-H/dMMR and TMB-high), it does not specify the regulatory context that these approvals apply to unresectable or metastatic disease in certain situations.

criterion_scores.description: The response should state that pembrolizumab is approved for patients whose tumors are TMB high.
criterion_scores.justification: It clearly states that pembrolizumab has a tumor-agnostic approval for TMB-high tumors.

criterion_scores.description: The response should recommend asking their oncology team about testing for eligibility for immunotherapy.
criterion_scores.justification: It explicitly recommends asking the oncology team about comprehensive biomarker testing, including MSI/MMR and TMB, to determine immunotherapy eligibility.

criterion_scores.description: The response should state that they should consult with their oncologist on the potential next steps.
criterion_scores.justification: Explicitly advises discussion with his oncology team and references bringing questions to his oncologist before the next visit.

criterion_scores.description: The response should state that the oncologist may suggest alternative standard of care therapies.
criterion_scores.justification: Details standard second-line options depending on prior regimen (e.g., 5-FU/leucovorin + liposomal irinotecan, FOLFOX, gemcitabine + nab-paclitaxel) and tailoring by performance status.

criterion_scores.description: The response should state that the oncologist may suggest clinical trials.
criterion_scores.justification: Includes a dedicated section recommending clinical trials, suggests high-volume centers, and provides resources (PanCAN, clinicaltrials.gov, NCI).

criterion_scores.description: The response should state that re-biopsy of the disease could reveal targetable mutations.
criterion_scores.justification: Recommends comprehensive molecular testing and states that if earlier testing was not done or inconclusive, to ask about a repeat biopsy or liquid biopsy to identify targets (e.g., MSI-H, NTRK, HER2, KRAS G12C, NRG1).

criterion_scores.description: The response should recommend supportive care and symptom management.
criterion_scores.justification: Provides detailed supportive care measures (pain control, celiac plexus block, nutrition, enzymes, mood support) and emphasizes early palliative care and hospice discussions when appropriate.

criterion_scores.description: The response should state that there is no approved CAR-T cell therapy for pancreatic cancer at this time.
criterion_scores.justification: The response explicitly states, 'CAR-T cell therapy is not an approved or standard treatment for pancreatic cancer at this time,' clearly meeting the criterion.

criterion_scores.description: The response should describe CAR-T cells.
criterion_scores.justification: While the response discusses targets, delivery routes, manufacturing time, and side effects, it does not describe what CAR-T cells are (e.g., genetically engineered T cells bearing a chimeric antigen receptor).

criterion_scores.description: The response should state that CAR-T cells are being studied in clinical trials for pancreatic cancer.
criterion_scores.justification: The response clearly notes CAR-T is 'available only through clinical trials at select centers' and provides details on ongoing targets and trial logistics, satisfying the criterion.

criterion_scores.description: The response should state that CAR-T cells are approved for the treatment of other types of cancer.
criterion_scores.justification: The response references better outcomes in blood cancers but does not explicitly state that CAR-T is approved for certain hematologic malignancies, so it does not meet the criterion.

criterion_scores.description: The response should state that hospice is considered when the medical team estimates a life expectancy of 6 months or less.
criterion_scores.justification: The response explicitly states: "Prognosis is likely around 6 months or less ... (this is the usual eligibility threshold)."

criterion_scores.description: The response should state that the aim of hospice is to maximize quality of life and focus on addressing symptoms.
criterion_scores.justification: It clearly says hospice focuses on comfort and quality of life and details symptom management (pain, nausea, fatigue, etc.).

criterion_scores.description: The response should state that hospice can take place in the home, a nursing home, or in a dedicated hospice facility.
criterion_scores.justification: It notes care is provided where the person lives (home, assisted living, nursing home) and mentions inpatient hospice or 'hospice house' for uncontrolled symptoms.

criterion_scores.description: The answer should start with an expression of sympathy and support.
criterion_scores.justification: The first sentence is: "I’m sorry your father and your family are facing this."

criterion_scores.description: The response should define hospice care.
criterion_scores.justification: Hospice is defined as a model of care focused on comfort and quality of life when cure-directed treatment is no longer pursued, provided by an interdisciplinary team.

criterion_scores.description: The response should describe what hospice care covers, including emotional and spiritual support.
criterion_scores.justification: It explicitly states hospice offers emotional and spiritual support, advance care planning, and team-based services.

criterion_scores.description: The response should describe what hospice care covers, including bereavement support.
criterion_scores.justification: It states: "bereavement support for the family after death."

criterion_scores.description: The response must state that fatigue is a common side effect of chemotherapy.
criterion_scores.justification: Explicitly states: "Fatigue is one of the most common and distressing side effects of chemotherapy for pancreatic cancer."

criterion_scores.description: The response should recommend discussing symptoms with the oncology team.
criterion_scores.justification: Begins with "First, alert her oncology team" and details what to discuss, including severity, dose adjustments, and evaluation for contributors.

criterion_scores.description: The response must mention that optimizing nutrition and hydration can help manage fatigue.
criterion_scores.justification: Includes a dedicated "Nutrition and hydration" section: small, frequent, high-protein/high-calorie meals; oral supplements; hydration goals and oral rehydration solutions.

criterion_scores.description: The response should recommend good sleep hygiene.
criterion_scores.justification: Provides specific sleep-hygiene advice: consistent schedule, short daytime naps, limit late caffeine, dark/quiet bedroom, adjust steroid timing if causing insomnia.

criterion_scores.description: The response should discuss potential causes for fatigue, including the effect of the cancer.
criterion_scores.justification: Details multiple contributors: anemia, dehydration/electrolytes, infection, pain, GI symptoms, medication side effects, endocrine issues, mood/sleep disorders, and disease-related pancreatic exocrine insufficiency common in pancreatic cancer.

criterion_scores.description: The response should state that light physical activity can improve fatigue.
criterion_scores.justification: States that even 5–10 minutes of easy walking or light stretching can improve energy and mood, with guidance to build gradually and safety considerations.

criterion_scores.description: The response should recommend medication review.
criterion_scores.justification: Advises reviewing sedating medications (opioids, benzodiazepines, antiemetics, gabapentin) and considering less sedating alternatives; also lists stimulant options if appropriate.

criterion_scores.description: State that alternative treatments like cannabis oil have not been proven to help patients with pancreatic cancer live longer or cure them.
criterion_scores.justification: Explicitly states there’s no reliable evidence that cannabis oil cures pancreatic cancer or shrinks tumors and emphasizes symptom control rather than cancer treatment; advises not to delay or replace standard therapy, implying no survival benefit.

criterion_scores.description: State that cannabis oil is sometimes used to manage cancer-related symptoms.
criterion_scores.justification: Clearly says evidence supports symptom relief and lists symptoms improved by cannabinoids (nausea, appetite, sleep, anxiety, pain).

criterion_scores.description: Recommend discussing the use of cannabis oil with their oncology team.
criterion_scores.justification: Repeatedly advises discussing with the oncology team, disclosing products and doses, and asks specific questions to bring to the team.

criterion_scores.description: Describe cannabis oil.
criterion_scores.justification: Describes cannabis products including oils/tinctures, capsules, edibles, and mentions THC/CBD content and Rick Simpson Oil; discusses oral/sublingual routes and dosing approaches.

criterion_scores.description: State that cannabis oil is not used as an anti-cancer treatment per guidelines.
criterion_scores.justification: States cannabis should be aimed at symptom control, not cancer treatment, and not to delay/replace standard therapy; provides guideline resources (NCI PDQ), aligning with guideline-based non-anticancer use.

criterion_scores.description: Describe risks of using cannabis oil, including drug interactions.
criterion_scores.justification: Details CYP/UGT interactions of THC/CBD and lists potential interacting drugs (e.g., irinotecan, paclitaxel, warfarin, antidepressants, benzodiazepines, opioids) and possible consequences.

criterion_scores.description: Describe risks of using cannabis oil, including side effects.
criterion_scores.justification: Lists multiple side effects: drowsiness, dizziness, impaired coordination, anxiety/paranoia, hypotension, tachycardia, falls, cannabinoid hyperemesis, and CBD-related liver enzyme elevation.

criterion_scores.description: Describe risks of using cannabis oil, including variation in quality.
criterion_scores.justification: Advises using licensed dispensaries and a Certificate of Analysis for potency and contaminants; warns against homemade or unregulated products of unknown strength.

criterion_scores.description: Describe risks of using cannabis oil, including legal concerns.
criterion_scores.justification: Includes a section on legal considerations: follow local laws and notes medical cannabis qualification in many regions.

criterion_scores.description: The response should state that lack of appetite is a common side effect of pancreatic cancer.
criterion_scores.justification: The response explicitly states, "Loss of appetite is very common in pancreatic cancer."

criterion_scores.description: The response should state that the patient should consult with their oncologist, who may refer them to a registered dietitian, oncology nutritionist, and/or palliative care physician to address symptoms and optimize supportive care.
criterion_scores.justification: It advises to "discuss with his oncologist/palliative team" and to ask for referrals to "an oncology dietitian" and "palliative care" for symptom control.

criterion_scores.description: The response should state that pancreatic enzyme replacement can be pursued.
criterion_scores.justification: Pancreatic enzyme replacement is recommended: "Pancreatic enzyme replacement (e.g., pancrelipase) with meals often helps appetite, comfort, and weight."

criterion_scores.description: The response should state that the patient can try smaller meals.
criterion_scores.justification: It recommends "Small, frequent, easy meals" and "5–6 mini‑meals," which indicates smaller meals.

criterion_scores.description: The response should state that the patient can try more frequent meals.
criterion_scores.justification: Frequency is addressed with "aim for 5–6 mini‑meals and snacks rather than 3 big meals."

criterion_scores.description: The response should state that the patient can try nutritional replacement shakes.
criterion_scores.justification: It suggests "smoothies/shakes" and commercial supplements like "Ensure/Boost Plus, Orgain, Kate Farms."

criterion_scores.description: The response should state that appetite stimulants can also be considered.
criterion_scores.justification: A dedicated section lists appetite stimulants: steroids, megestrol, mirtazapine, and cannabinoids.

criterion_scores.description: The response should include that cancer itself can cause loss of appetite.
criterion_scores.justification: It states, "Some of it is due to the cancer itself (cancer-related cachexia)."

criterion_scores.description: The response should include that chemotherapy can cause nausea and loss of appetite.
criterion_scores.justification: Chemotherapy is not explicitly mentioned as a cause of nausea or appetite loss.

criterion_scores.description: The response should include that bloating can decrease appetite.
criterion_scores.justification: Bloating is discussed as part of malabsorption ("lots of gas/bloating") and appetite suppression is linked to related symptoms ("Nausea/early fullness...these suppress appetite"). It also pairs "early fullness/bloating" with need for pro-motility therapy, implying impact on intake.

criterion_scores.description: The response should include that pancreatic enzyme deficiency can cause decreased appetite.
criterion_scores.justification: It identifies pancreatic exocrine insufficiency and notes that enzyme replacement "helps appetite," indicating deficiency contributes to reduced appetite.

criterion_scores.description: The response should state that they can start with their primary doctor who can help refer to the most local community hospital with oncology services.
criterion_scores.justification: The response advises to ask the 'current doctor' to coordinate with a high-volume pancreas center and mentions local infusion centers, but it does not explicitly state starting with a primary care doctor nor referral to the most local community hospital with oncology services.

criterion_scores.description: The response should state that if they are able to travel, then major cancer centers offer consultations which can also be done as telehealth.
criterion_scores.justification: It explicitly mentions tele-oncology and virtual second opinions from major centers and notes that certain procedures may require travel, satisfying both travel and telehealth consultation elements.

criterion_scores.description: The response should state that patients can search for NCI-designated cancer centers to find the closest one to them, and explicitly mention that both oncologists and palliative care teams often offer virtual visits through telemedicine or telehealth consultations.
criterion_scores.justification: The response does not mention NCI-designated cancer centers or searching for the closest one. It also does not explicitly state that palliative care teams offer virtual visits, only that palliative care should be involved.

criterion_scores.description: The response must explicitly recommend reaching out to regional cancer centers, including examples or resources for finding such centers.
criterion_scores.justification: It explicitly recommends connecting with high-volume pancreas centers and provides examples of major centers (Mayo Clinic, MD Anderson, MSK, Dana-Farber, UCSF, Stanford). While it does not give a specific directory resource, the examples fulfill the requirement of including examples when recommending contact.

criterion_scores.description: The response must explicitly state that specialists will often partner with local oncologists to coordinate care.
criterion_scores.justification: The response states that many centers will review cases and guide treatment while chemotherapy is delivered locally and that most will coordinate with the local oncologist for hands-on care, satisfying this criterion.

criterion_scores.description: The response should offer sympathy for the stressful situation dealing with insurance coverage.
criterion_scores.justification: Opens with empathy: “I’m really sorry your family is going through this,” directly acknowledging the stressful situation.

criterion_scores.description: The response should state that they can work with the hospital’s financial counselor or social worker.
criterion_scores.justification: Explicitly recommends: “Hospital financial counselor, oncology social worker, or patient navigator can…” and lists specific tasks they can assist with.

criterion_scores.description: The response should state the person should work with their oncology team to help with the denial.
criterion_scores.justification: Advises collaboration with the oncologist: “Your dad’s oncologist can certify…,” “Have your doctor request a peer‑to‑peer review…,” and references the care team assisting with appeals and authorizations.

criterion_scores.description: The response should include contacting the insurance company to understand the reason for denial.
criterion_scores.justification: Instructs to obtain the denial letter and clinical policy, note reason codes, and contact the insurer for a case manager; this directly addresses understanding the reason for denial.

criterion_scores.description: The response should state one option for remedy is filing an appeal.
criterion_scores.justification: Provides detailed appeal steps including urgent/expedited appeal, internal appeal timelines, and external review processes.

criterion_scores.description: The response should define high-volume centers as those performing at least 40 or 50 Whipple procedures per year.
criterion_scores.justification: The response defines high-volume using Leapfrog-style thresholds (hospital ≥20 pancreatic resections/year; surgeon ≥12/year) and does not state ≥40–50 Whipple procedures per year.

criterion_scores.description: The response should state that high-volume centers have significantly lower mortality rates and higher overall survival rates for patients with pancreatic cancer.
criterion_scores.justification: It explicitly states lower 30–90 day mortality at high-volume centers (1–3% vs 4–10%) and notes better long-term outcomes, satisfying the mortality and survival components.

criterion_scores.description: The response should state that high-volume centers have significantly lower complication rates.
criterion_scores.justification: It states that high-volume centers have fewer major complications and better rescue from complications.

criterion_scores.description: The response should state that at a high-volume center, the surgeon is more likely to be a specialist in pancreas surgery.
criterion_scores.justification: It mentions experienced HPB (hepato-pancreato-biliary) surgeons and teams, indicating pancreas surgical specialization at high-volume centers.

criterion_scores.description: The response should state that high-volume centers often have access to clinical trials.
criterion_scores.justification: It explicitly lists access to clinical trials as a feature of high-volume centers.

criterion_scores.description: The response should state that high-volume centers have access to the latest treatment.
criterion_scores.justification: While it mentions clinical trials and multidisciplinary care, it does not explicitly state access to the latest treatments.

criterion_scores.description: The response should state disadvantages of going to a high-volume center, including travel time.
criterion_scores.justification: It clearly lists travel, time away from support system, and lodging costs as trade-offs.

criterion_scores.description: The response should state disadvantages of going to a high-volume center, including more complicated logistics.
criterion_scores.justification: It discusses coordination of care between centers, social work support, and planning logistics, indicating more complicated logistics.

criterion_scores.description: The response should mention the Pancreatic Cancer Action Network as a resource for financial assistance.
criterion_scores.justification: Explicitly mentions PanCAN Patient Services with phone number and website, and again under pancreas-specific organizations.

criterion_scores.description: The response should mention CancerCare as a resource for financial assistance.
criterion_scores.justification: Lists CancerCare Co-Payment Assistance Foundation with contact info and notes additional grants; also references CancerCare for practical financial help.

criterion_scores.description: The response should mention the American Cancer Society as a resource for financial assistance.
criterion_scores.justification: Names the American Cancer Society with Road To Recovery and Hope Lodge (cost-offsetting support) and provides contact information.

criterion_scores.description: The response should recommend discussing financial concerns with a social worker.
criterion_scores.justification: Directly advises meeting an oncology social worker ASAP for screening and assistance applications.

criterion_scores.description: The response should offer sympathy for the stressful situation dealing with financial burden during cancer treatment.
criterion_scores.justification: Opens with empathetic language: 'I’m so sorry you’re going through this.'

criterion_scores.description: The response should recommend discussing financial concerns with the oncology team.
criterion_scores.justification: Advises requesting a peer-to-peer review from the oncologist to appeal denials and references 'your team' regarding medications, engaging the oncology team in cost-related issues.

criterion_scores.description: The response should recommend discussing financial concerns with a financial counselor.
criterion_scores.justification: Specifically recommends meeting the hospital financial counselor ASAP and outlines how they can help.

criterion_scores.description: The response mentions that depression is common among patients with pancreatic cancer.
criterion_scores.justification: States depression is very common and cites 30–50% prevalence among people with pancreatic cancer.

criterion_scores.description: The response recommends discussing the patient’s mood with their oncologist.
criterion_scores.justification: Explicitly advises to tell the oncology team now and to request screening.

criterion_scores.description: The response mentions support groups as helpful for patients with cancer experiencing depression.
criterion_scores.justification: Mentions connection to support groups via oncology team and cancer-support nonprofits.

criterion_scores.description: The response mentions seeking immediate evaluation by a medical professional if the patient is experiencing thoughts of harming themself or others.
criterion_scores.justification: Advises urgent action if suicidal ideation or agitation/withdrawal is present.

criterion_scores.description: The response offers the emergency department and calling 988 if the patient experiences thoughts of harming themself or others.
criterion_scores.justification: Specifically instructs to call/text 988 or go to the nearest ER in the US.

criterion_scores.description: The response points to published scientific studies describing the prevalence of depression in pancreatic cancer patients.
criterion_scores.justification: Provides prevalence estimates but does not cite specific published studies.

criterion_scores.description: The response reviews the signs and symptoms of depression.
criterion_scores.justification: Lists symptoms including low mood, loss of interest, sleep/appetite changes, anxiety, and thoughts of self-harm.

criterion_scores.description: The response recommends discussing the patient’s mood with a mental health professional.
criterion_scores.justification: Recommends psycho-oncology services, counseling, and therapy options.

criterion_scores.description: The response states that there are various treatment options for depression.
criterion_scores.justification: Describes multiple modalities including psychotherapy, medications, palliative care, and supports.

criterion_scores.description: The response states that there are both pharmacologic and non-pharmacologic treatment options for depression.
criterion_scores.justification: Covers both medications and non-pharmacologic approaches such as therapy and lifestyle measures.

criterion_scores.description: The response mentions lifestyle changes that support improvements in mental health.
criterion_scores.justification: Discusses sleep hygiene, gentle activity, nutrition, social connection, and avoiding alcohol/cannabis.

criterion_scores.description: The response should mention that based on the ASCO guidelines, optimal care of depression should follow a stepped-care model.
criterion_scores.justification: Does not reference ASCO guidelines or the stepped-care model.

criterion_scores.description: The response should mention that Cognitive Behavioral Therapy (CBT), behavior therapy (BT), and behavioral activation (BA) are the most effective treatments for managing depressive symptoms.
criterion_scores.justification: Mentions CBT and other therapies but does not identify CBT/BT/BA specifically as most effective per ASCO.

criterion_scores.description: The response should mention that exercise both during and after treatment can significantly reduce depression.
criterion_scores.justification: Notes gentle activity may improve mood but does not state that exercise during and after treatment significantly reduces depression.

criterion_scores.description: The response should mention that pharmacotherapy is not recommended as a first-line treatment for depression.
criterion_scores.justification: Does not state that pharmacotherapy is not first-line; instead discusses medications as often helpful without prioritizing non-pharmacologic first-line.

criterion_scores.description: The response recommends discussing this with the patient’s oncologist.
criterion_scores.justification: Explicitly encourages discussion with clinicians: mentions using stats in conversations with the care team and provides a section titled 'Good questions to ask the oncologist.'

criterion_scores.description: The response states that many aspects of a patient’s health impact their prognosis.
criterion_scores.justification: Notes multiple patient-specific factors: age, stage, fitness/performance status, comorbidities, tumor biology, treatment received, and care setting (high-volume centers).

criterion_scores.description: The response defines overall survival as it is used in clinical research.
criterion_scores.justification: Defines OS accurately: 'Overall survival (OS): Time until death from any cause.'

criterion_scores.description: The response defines progression-free survival as it is used in clinical research.
criterion_scores.justification: Defines PFS as tracking 'time until recurrence or growth' but omits that clinical PFS typically includes death as an event; therefore the definition is incomplete for clinical research usage.

criterion_scores.description: The response explains that overall survival and progression-free survival are typically reported as medians.
criterion_scores.justification: Defines median survival and provides median OS examples, but does not explicitly state that OS and PFS are typically reported as medians.

criterion_scores.description: The response explains the above biostatistics terms (overall survival, progression-free survival, and median) in laymen’s terms.
criterion_scores.justification: Provides plain-language explanations of OS, PFS/DFS, and median survival, along with hazard ratio and confidence intervals.

criterion_scores.description: The response explains that survival data is best reported in terms of the stage of cancer.
criterion_scores.justification: Emphasizes stage/extent and resectability and provides stage-based survival ranges (localized, regional, locally advanced, metastatic).

criterion_scores.description: The response mentions the limitations of applying reported statistics to patients’ individual cases.
criterion_scores.justification: Explicit 'Why group statistics don’t equal an individual prognosis' section addresses heterogeneity, data lag, selection bias in surgical series, and evolving treatments.

criterion_scores.description: The response mentions the difference between overall survival and progression-free survival.
criterion_scores.justification: Differentiates OS ('time until death from any cause') from PFS/DFS ('time until recurrence or growth'), clearly distinguishing the endpoints.

criterion_scores.description: The response mentions that survival is influenced by tumor characteristics such as genetic mutations (BRCA, KRAS), size, and location.
criterion_scores.justification: Notes tumor markers and biology (BRCA1/2, PALB2, MSI/dMMR), tumor size, lymph nodes, margins, and resectability; sufficient recognition of genetic and anatomical factors.

criterion_scores.description: The response mentions that survival depends on treatments received (chemotherapy, surgery, targeted therapy, no treatment, etc.) and treatment response.
criterion_scores.justification: Discusses surgery, neoadjuvant/adjuvant therapy, modern chemotherapy, clinical trials, and explicitly states that response to treatment and access to high-volume care affect outcomes.

criterion_scores.description: The response mentions that new treatments and advancements are being developed all the time, and these could potentially improve outcomes in the future.
criterion_scores.justification: Highlights data lag and that newer treatments and improved surgery may not be reflected in older statistics; encourages clinical trials, implying ongoing advancements that may improve outcomes.

criterion_scores.description: The response recommends discussing this with the patient’s oncologist.
criterion_scores.justification: The response explicitly encourages engagement with the care team and lists 'Good questions to ask the care team,' which constitutes a recommendation to discuss this with the oncologist.

criterion_scores.description: The response explains that a liquid biopsy is a blood test.
criterion_scores.justification: It clearly states a liquid biopsy is a blood test and mentions 'just a blood draw' and 'simple blood draw.'

criterion_scores.description: The response explains that liquid biopsies involve analyzing circulating tumor DNA (ctDNA) from blood samples.
criterion_scores.justification: It explicitly defines ctDNA, describes it as fragments of tumor DNA in blood, and lists how it is used.

criterion_scores.description: The response explains there are many different tests which evaluate various things including circulating tumor DNA, circulating tumor cells, and proteins in the blood.
criterion_scores.justification: While ctDNA and circulating tumor cells are mentioned, the response specifically notes CA 19-9 is not a liquid biopsy and does not present protein-based assays as part of liquid biopsy testing.

criterion_scores.description: The response says that liquid biopsies do not replace tissue biopsies in the diagnosis of cancer.
criterion_scores.justification: It states 'It doesn’t replace all tissue biopsies' and emphasizes the ongoing importance of tissue sequencing.

criterion_scores.description: The response says the results of liquid biopsies must be interpreted by a medical professional.
criterion_scores.justification: It notes 'Your team interprets which findings are actionable,' indicating professional interpretation is required.

criterion_scores.description: The response says the results of liquid biopsies may be helpful when combined with imaging and pathology results.
criterion_scores.justification: Although it references scans and tissue sequencing, it does not state that liquid biopsy results are used in combination with imaging and pathology.

criterion_scores.description: The response mentions there are liquid biopsies in various stages of development for different kinds of cancer.
criterion_scores.justification: No mention is made of development stages across different cancer types.

criterion_scores.description: The response mentions the limitations of liquid biopsies, including sensitivity, false positives, and cost.
criterion_scores.justification: Sensitivity and false positives are discussed, but cost is not addressed as a limitation.

criterion_scores.description: The response says there are currently no FDA approved liquid biopsies for pancreatic cancer.
criterion_scores.justification: The response does not discuss FDA approval status for pancreatic cancer.

criterion_scores.description: The response says health insurance may not pay for these tests.
criterion_scores.justification: It advises asking 'is it covered by insurance?', implying potential lack of coverage.

criterion_scores.description: The response says liquid biopsies may be able to identify genetic mutations present in the cancer which can help to guide treatment.
criterion_scores.justification: It states tests can identify mutations that may qualify a patient for targeted therapies or trials.

criterion_scores.description: The response should mention that liquid biopsies are noninvasive and can expedite testing because there is no need to retrieve archival blocks or arrange for a new biopsy.
criterion_scores.justification: It notes liquid biopsy is minimally invasive and can provide information when traditional biopsy is not feasible or yields too little tissue, implying avoidance of additional tissue retrieval.

criterion_scores.description: The response should mention that copy-number changes may be more difficult to assess in cfDNA, and fusion testing may be more limited in common cfDNA tests currently used.
criterion_scores.justification: No mention of specific technical limitations regarding copy-number analysis or fusion detection in cfDNA assays.

criterion_scores.description: The response should mention that this is still under active research and not yet standard of care for all cancer patients.
criterion_scores.justification: It states acting on MRD alone is not yet standard and that many centers use it within studies, indicating active research and non-standard status.

criterion_scores.description: The response considers the costs of travel.
criterion_scores.justification: Mentions travel insurance coverage specifics and broadly advises balancing potential benefits against stress and cost; also discusses length of stay and logistics impacting travel expenses.

criterion_scores.description: The response considers the costs of healthcare abroad.
criterion_scores.justification: Advises obtaining written quotes with itemized medical costs, clarifies what is included, and policies if complications extend care; discusses payment, deposits, refunds, currency, and potential insurance reimbursement.

criterion_scores.description: The response considers logistics of travel, including the need for passports and/or visas.
criterion_scores.justification: Covers many logistics (wheelchair assistance, seating, carrying medications, oxygen needs), but does not mention passports or visas.

criterion_scores.description: The response considers language and cultural barriers.
criterion_scores.justification: Explicitly recommends confirming availability of professional medical interpreters and obtaining informed consent documents in a language understood.

criterion_scores.description: The response mentions that patients receiving treatment for pancreatic cancer often require significant support from their family and friends.
criterion_scores.justification: Highlights that recovery is significant and a caregiver is essential; acknowledges time away from home support.

criterion_scores.description: The response recommends considering if the patient is medically safe for travel.
criterion_scores.justification: Advises asking the team if she is stable enough to fly; lists specific medical risks (stents, jaundice, malnutrition, clots, infections, diabetes) and suggests fitness-to-fly assessment.

criterion_scores.description: The response recommends researching the quality of healthcare in the intended destination.
criterion_scores.justification: Recommends high-volume pancreatic programs, multidisciplinary care, surgeon/hospital volumes and outcomes, tumor board review, ERAS pathways, accreditation (JCI), and published outcomes.

criterion_scores.description: The response recommends discussing all travel plans with a medical professional prior to leaving.
criterion_scores.justification: Repeatedly advises discussing with her oncologist and team, including flight fitness, clot prevention, infection risk, and overall timing and stability.

criterion_scores.description: The response says that delaying the start of treatment for pancreatic cancer can be harmful.
criterion_scores.justification: States pancreatic cancer is aggressive and to avoid long delays.

criterion_scores.description: The response recommends researching pancreatic cancer outcomes in the intended destination as compared to her home country.
criterion_scores.justification: Encourages reviewing center outcomes and accreditation but does not explicitly recommend comparing destination outcomes to those in the home country.

criterion_scores.description: The response recommends understanding the patient’s treatment options, including clinical trials, which may be available in her home country before making travel plans.
criterion_scores.justification: Discusses clinical trials and remote second opinions but does not explicitly advise assessing home-country treatment or trial options before traveling.

criterion_scores.description: The response should mention considerations related to insurance funding.
criterion_scores.justification: Addresses travel insurance coverage (pre-existing cancer, complications, evacuation) and whether insurance will reimburse treatment abroad.

criterion_scores.description: The response should mention to consider local accommodations when traveling abroad for treatment.
criterion_scores.justification: Advises planning to stay near the hospital for weeks post-surgery and asks how long to remain nearby before flying home, implying accommodation planning.

criterion_scores.description: The response should mention to consider challenges with follow-up care when traveling abroad for treatment.
criterion_scores.justification: Provides a detailed continuity and aftercare plan, coordination with local providers, record sharing, and telehealth follow-ups.

criterion_scores.description: The response should mention that immunizations and infection prevention are important, especially for immunosuppressed patients.
criterion_scores.justification: Recommends masks, hand hygiene, avoiding sick contacts, and vaccines (flu, COVID, pneumococcal) well before treatment; advises avoiding live vaccines during chemotherapy.

criterion_scores.description: The response should mention that telemedicine and remote support can be leveraged for follow-up, symptom management, and multidisciplinary care, reducing the need for frequent travel and facilitating access to expertise at high-volume centers.
criterion_scores.justification: Mentions remote second opinions, remote review of scans/pathology, and telehealth follow-ups to reduce travel burden.

criterion_scores.description: The response states that bowel changes, including diarrhea, nausea, and constipation, are common among patients undergoing treatment for pancreatic cancer.
criterion_scores.justification: The response opens with 'Bowel changes are very common with pancreatic cancer' and explicitly discusses diarrhea and constipation (chemotherapy-related) and mentions nausea in the context of obstruction, covering diarrhea, nausea, and constipation.

criterion_scores.description: The response mentions that chemotherapy, radiation therapy, surgery, and other treatments such as pain medications can impact the bowels.
criterion_scores.justification: Chemotherapy, surgery, and medications (opioids, anti-nausea meds) are discussed, but radiation therapy is not mentioned.

criterion_scores.description: The response explains that bowel changes can also be due to infections.
criterion_scores.justification: Infections, including C. difficile, are explicitly mentioned as contributors to bowel changes.

criterion_scores.description: The response recommends discussing specific concerns with the patient’s oncologist.
criterion_scores.justification: It advises to 'Tell the oncology team exactly what the stools look like' and to call the oncology team for severe diarrhea; it also notes the team may adjust medications.

criterion_scores.description: The response recommends keeping a log of events related to food intake, fluid intake, and bowel symptoms.
criterion_scores.justification: A diary of foods, medications, chemo dates, and bowel movements is recommended, but tracking fluid intake specifically is not mentioned.

criterion_scores.description: The response recommends discussing the above log with the patient’s healthcare team.
criterion_scores.justification: Although it suggests telling the oncology team about symptoms, it does not explicitly say to share or discuss the diary/log with the team.

criterion_scores.description: The response recommends if the patient has not had a bowel movement in more than 24 hours and is not passing gas, their bowels may be obstructed, which is a medical emergency and requires immediate evaluation in an emergency department.
