criterion_scores.justification: It discusses poor appetite and end-of-life considerations but does not state that lack of desire to eat/drink may be the body's natural signal of nearing end of life.

criterion_scores.description: The response states studies have shown that in the absence of a bowel obstruction, feeding tubes do not typically increase survival in patients with cancer.
criterion_scores.justification: It notes tube feeding usually does not prolong life near end of life but does not reference studies or specify the 'absence of bowel obstruction' condition.

criterion_scores.description: The response recommends considering hospice care.
criterion_scores.justification: Palliative care is recommended, but hospice is not mentioned.

criterion_scores.description: The response states that malnutrition is common in patients with pancreatic cancer.
criterion_scores.justification: Malnutrition is discussed as a concern but the response does not state it is common in pancreatic cancer.

criterion_scores.description: The response reviews the risks of feeding tubes, including discomfort and infection.
criterion_scores.justification: It lists infection risks and multiple discomfort-related issues (cramping, reflux, skin leakage), as well as other complications (aspiration, bleeding, perforation).

criterion_scores.description: The response recommends discussing the patient’s goals of care.
criterion_scores.justification: It emphasizes clarifying goals of care and suggests palliative care involvement to align treatment with goals.

criterion_scores.description: The response should mention that pancreatic cancer can cause digestive issues due to a blocked bile duct.
criterion_scores.justification: It explicitly mentions addressing biliary obstruction (stent), which corresponds to blocked bile duct issues.

criterion_scores.description: The response should mention that pancreatic cancer can cause digestive issues due to a blocked stomach.
criterion_scores.justification: It discusses gastric outlet obstruction and duodenal obstruction and possible stenting/bypass.

criterion_scores.description: The response should mention that pancreatic cancer can cause digestive issues due to low levels of digestive enzymes.
criterion_scores.justification: It recommends pancreatic enzyme replacement therapy (PERT) for exocrine insufficiency.

criterion_scores.description: The response should mention that pancreatic cancer can cause digestive issues due to loss of appetite.
criterion_scores.justification: It notes poor appetite without obstruction as a reason for eating difficulties.

criterion_scores.description: The response should mention that pancreatic cancer can cause digestive issues due to cancer-related pain.
criterion_scores.justification: It advises managing pain among other symptoms as part of optimizing nutrition, implying pain contributes to intake/digestive issues.

criterion_scores.description: The response should mention that nutritional counseling is recommended for patients with pancreatic cancer.
criterion_scores.justification: It recommends involving a registered dietitian and provides dietary strategies, which constitutes nutritional counseling.

criterion_scores.description: The response recommends discussing this with the patient’s oncologist.
criterion_scores.justification: The response explicitly advises involving the oncology team: "Ask your oncology team for a referral..." and "Your cancer center’s social worker or child life specialist (ask your oncology team)." This constitutes recommending discussion with the oncologist/oncology team.

criterion_scores.description: The response recommends involving a professional who can help with these challenging conversations, like a social worker or spiritual counselor.
criterion_scores.justification: It recommends multiple professionals: social worker, child life specialist, pediatric therapist, family counselor, and school counselor. These are appropriate professionals for supporting such conversations.

criterion_scores.description: The response recommends online resources for patients with cancer, including cancer.org.
criterion_scores.justification: It lists several reputable online resources, including the American Cancer Society (which is cancer.org), National Cancer Institute, CancerCare, Cancer Support Community, Pancreatic Cancer UK, Macmillan, and others.

criterion_scores.description: The response recommends clear and honest language.
criterion_scores.justification: It repeatedly emphasizes honesty and clarity: "Use the correct word cancer," "Be honest and hopeful," and provides clear sample language, including for difficult topics like prognosis.

criterion_scores.description: The response recommends tailoring the conversation to the children’s ages.
criterion_scores.justification: It provides detailed age-specific guidance for preschoolers, school-age children, and teens, including sample wording tailored to developmental level.

criterion_scores.description: The response should mention to avoid overwhelming the child with too much information at once; provide information in small doses, stopping frequently to check for comprehension.
criterion_scores.justification: While it advises "Share a little, often" and frames this as a series of talks, it does not explicitly recommend pausing or checking for comprehension during conversations.

criterion_scores.description: The response should mention to arrange for an appropriate location for the conversation and ensure there is enough time to give the information and answer questions.
criterion_scores.justification: It advises planning "who will tell them and when: choose a quiet time," which implies a calm, appropriate setting and not being rushed. It also encourages open questions ("You can ask any question, any time"), indicating time to answer.

criterion_scores.description: The response should mention to provide information that is relevant to what the child wants to know.
criterion_scores.justification: It encourages guiding content by the child’s interests and questions: "You can ask any question, any time," offers age-relevant information, and includes preparing for common questions, which focuses on what children want to know.

criterion_scores.description: The response should mention to respond empathically to the child’s emotions and acknowledge their feelings throughout the conversation.
criterion_scores.justification: It explicitly promotes empathy and validation: "it’s okay to have all kinds of feelings," "Name and normalize feelings," and modeling adults having feelings and still functioning.

criterion_scores.description: The response states that sleep patterns can be disturbed by cancer and its treatments.
criterion_scores.justification: It explicitly says, 'changes in sleep are very common with pancreatic cancer and its treatments,' and further cites chemo/radiation effects.

criterion_scores.description: The response states that sleep patterns can be disturbed by symptoms like fatigue, pain, and nausea.
criterion_scores.justification: Lists 'Cancer-related fatigue,' and 'Pain, nausea' as reasons for disturbed sleep.

criterion_scores.description: The response states that sleep patterns can be a symptom of anxiety and depression.
criterion_scores.justification: Specifically mentions 'anxiety/depression disrupting sleep' as a cause.

criterion_scores.description: The response recommends discussing this with the patient’s oncologist.
criterion_scores.justification: Advises, 'Let his oncology or palliative care team know about the changes' and to adjust/assess causes.

criterion_scores.description: The response recommends tracking the sleep disturbances and sharing this with the patient’s healthcare team.
criterion_scores.justification: Recommends keeping 'a brief sleep/medication/symptom log' to identify patterns.

criterion_scores.description: The response recommends sleep hygiene techniques.
criterion_scores.justification: Provides multiple sleep hygiene measures: morning daylight, gentle activity, limiting naps, consistent routine, quiet/dark room, limiting screens/caffeine, and symptom control before bed.

criterion_scores.description: The response states other options for treatment may include supplements like melatonin, cognitive behavioral therapy, or prescribed medications.
criterion_scores.justification: Mentions 'melatonin' explicitly as a possible sleep aid and to discuss options with clinicians.

criterion_scores.description: The response recommends seeking immediate medical evaluation if the changes in sleep patterns are sudden or severe.
criterion_scores.justification: Gives clear urgent red flags including 'very hard to wake,' new confusion/hallucinations, fever/infection, severe breathing problems, etc., prompting urgent care.

criterion_scores.description: The response should mention that non-pharmacological interventions like relaxation techniques, cognitive behavioral therapy for insomnia, and mindfulness can be beneficial.
criterion_scores.justification: Does not mention relaxation techniques, CBT-I, or mindfulness; only sleep hygiene and melatonin are discussed.

criterion_scores.description: The response should mention that addressing underlying causes of sleep disruption, such as pain management or treatment of anxiety/depression, is important.
criterion_scores.justification: Advises clinicians check for reversible causes and adjust meds; specifically recommends managing 'pain/nausea/itch before bed,' indicating focus on underlying causes.

criterion_scores.description: The response recommends discussing complementary therapies with the patient’s oncologist.
criterion_scores.justification: Explicitly advises coordinating with the oncology team and seeking oncology approval, including sharing blood counts and treatment-specific cautions.

criterion_scores.description: The response states complementary therapies like acupuncture may improve symptoms related to cancer and its treatments and may improve cancer patients’ quality of life.
criterion_scores.justification: States acupuncture can help with nausea, pain, CIPN, anxiety, and fatigue; also mentions mind-body and massage benefits, implying improved quality of life.

criterion_scores.description: The response states complementary therapies are not a safe alternative to standard cancer treatments.
criterion_scores.justification: Clearly notes acupuncture "won’t treat the cancer itself" and cites use as an adjunct to standard care, indicating it should not replace standard treatments.

criterion_scores.description: The response states complementary therapies are not as effective as standard of care cancer treatments.
criterion_scores.justification: States acupuncture does not treat the cancer and is an adjunct, which conveys it is not as effective as standard cancer treatments.

criterion_scores.description: The response defines complementary therapies and provides examples, including acupuncture.
criterion_scores.justification: Describes integrative/complementary therapies as adjuncts for symptom relief and provides examples (acupuncture, mind-body practices, massage, acupressure, herbs/supplements, cannabis).

criterion_scores.description: The response recommends informing the patient’s oncologist of any supplements the patient starts taking.
criterion_scores.justification: Advises not starting herbs/supplements without oncology approval, which encompasses informing the oncologist.

criterion_scores.description: The response states supplements are not regulated by the FDA.
criterion_scores.justification: Does not mention FDA regulation status of supplements.

criterion_scores.description: The response states some supplements may interact with certain treatments for pancreatic cancer.
criterion_scores.justification: Lists specific interaction risks (e.g., St. John’s wort with irinotecan, bleeding risk with turmeric/garlic/ginger, antioxidant effects on chemo/radiation, fish oil timing).

criterion_scores.description: The response reviews the risks of acupuncture, including bleeding and infection, which may be increased in patients receiving chemotherapy.
criterion_scores.justification: Addresses bleeding risk (low platelets, anticoagulants) and infection risk (neutropenia, fever, signs of infection), with chemo-related precautions.

criterion_scores.description: The response recommends utilizing a practitioner licensed in acupuncture.
criterion_scores.justification: Specifically advises choosing a licensed acupuncturist or medical acupuncturist with oncology experience.

criterion_scores.description: The response should mention that acupuncture is generally safe for cancer patients, with no increased risk of serious adverse events compared to sham or standard care, though mild side effects such as bruising, soreness, or transient discomfort may occur.
criterion_scores.justification: States acupuncture is generally safe and mentions minor side effects; however, it does not explicitly state there is no increased risk of serious adverse events compared to sham or standard care.

criterion_scores.description: The response explicitly recommends discussing balance problems with the patient’s oncologist or healthcare team immediately.
criterion_scores.justification: The response instructs, "Contact his oncology team today to report the balance changes," which is a clear, immediate recommendation to involve the care team.

criterion_scores.description: The response clearly states that symptoms from pancreatic cancer and its treatment, such as fatigue, headache, muscle weakness, and peripheral neuropathy, may contribute to sensations of imbalance.
criterion_scores.justification: It cites treatment-related peripheral neuropathy, fatigue (from targeted agents), and muscle weakness (from steroids) as contributors to imbalance. Although headache is noted as a red flag, the criterion is satisfied by inclusion of fatigue, muscle weakness, and neuropathy.

criterion_scores.description: The response should mention that chemotherapy can cause peripheral neuropathy, fatigue, anemia, and generalized weakness, which can all cause instability.
criterion_scores.justification: While chemotherapy-induced peripheral neuropathy is clearly stated, the response does not explicitly attribute fatigue, anemia, or generalized weakness to chemotherapy specifically. Anemia is listed as a cause in general, and weakness is attributed to steroids, not chemo.

criterion_scores.description: The response should mention that pancreatic cancer itself increases the risk of thromboembolic events, including cerebral ischemic strokes, which may present with acute balance disturbances or ataxia.
criterion_scores.justification: It explicitly states, "pancreatic cancer increases clot risk, and sudden imbalance can be a stroke," fulfilling the requirement.

criterion_scores.description: The response explicitly instructs seeking immediate medical evaluation if symptoms are abrupt, severe, or accompanied by other neurologic deficits.
criterion_scores.justification: The "Red flags—call emergency services now" section lists abrupt neurologic deficits (e.g., one-sided weakness, facial droop, slurred speech), clearly directing immediate evaluation.

criterion_scores.description: The response explicitly states that balance problems can lead to falls.
criterion_scores.justification: Although fall-prevention measures are recommended and steroids are said to cause weakness and falls, the response does not explicitly connect balance problems themselves to fall risk.

criterion_scores.description: The response explicitly recommends ensuring the patient drinks plenty of fluids.
criterion_scores.justification: It advises, "Practical steps now: hydrate regularly," which is an explicit recommendation to maintain fluid intake.

criterion_scores.description: The response explicitly recommends the patient stand and walk with assistance until they can be evaluated by their healthcare team.
criterion_scores.justification: It recommends fall-prevention strategies and to "consider a cane/walker temporarily" and to "supervise showers," which constitutes advising assisted ambulation pending evaluation.

criterion_scores.description: The response recommends reviewing the pathology report with the patient’s oncologist or healthcare team.
criterion_scores.justification: It provides a section 'What to ask the care team' with specific questions and advises requesting the CAP synoptic report and even a second-opinion review, clearly encouraging discussion with the care team.

criterion_scores.description: The response states that pathology reports are written by doctors called pathologists who view tissue under the microscope to diagnose diseases.
criterion_scores.justification: It does not explain that pathologists create the report or that they examine tissue under a microscope.

criterion_scores.description: The response states the pathology report will contain a tumor type.
criterion_scores.justification: It lists 'Histologic type' and specifies PDAC and variants; also distinguishes adenocarcinoma vs neuroendocrine tumors.

criterion_scores.description: The response states the pathology report may contain a stage of the cancer.
criterion_scores.justification: It details 'Pathologic stage (AJCC 8th edition)' and pTNM/ypTNM notation.

criterion_scores.description: The response states the pathology report may contain a tumor size.
criterion_scores.justification: It includes 'Tumor size and location' and explains its role in T category.

criterion_scores.description: The response states the pathology report may contain a tumor grade.
criterion_scores.justification: It has a dedicated 'Grade' section (well/moderately/poorly differentiated).

criterion_scores.description: The response states the pathology report may mention vascular invasion.
criterion_scores.justification: It discusses 'Lymphovascular invasion (LVI)' explicitly.

criterion_scores.description: The response states the pathology report may mention perineural invasion.
criterion_scores.justification: It discusses 'Perineural invasion (PNI)' explicitly.

criterion_scores.description: The response states the pathology report may contain special stains which can sometimes be used to determine additional treatment options.
criterion_scores.justification: Although it mentions MSI/MMR and molecular profiling, it does not mention 'special stains' or immunohistochemistry as such.

criterion_scores.description: The response states the final stage ranges from I to IV and is a sum of a tumor (T) score, a node (N) score, and a metastasis (M) score.
criterion_scores.justification: It explains T, N, M categories but does not state that overall stage groups I–IV are derived from these.

criterion_scores.description: The response states the pathology report helps the oncologist determine which treatment may be the most effective.
criterion_scores.justification: It states stage and margin status drive recommendations for adjuvant therapy and that MSI/genomic findings can open targeted therapies or trials, linking the report to treatment decisions.

criterion_scores.description: The response states the pathology report may include results from genetic testing of the tumor which may help in identifying targeted therapy.
criterion_scores.justification: It includes 'Tumor molecular profiling' with actionable alterations (e.g., NTRK, BRAF, KRAS G12C) and notes MSI-high can be treated with immunotherapy.

criterion_scores.description: The response must mention margin status, including the presence of the tumor at or within 1 mm of any resection margin (R1), and its impact on prognosis and adjuvant therapy decisions.
criterion_scores.justification: It defines R0/R1/R2, notes some centers report distance in mm and that closer than 1 mm is often noted, emphasizes the uncinate/SMA margin, and states margins influence prognosis and adjuvant therapy recommendations.

criterion_scores.description: The response must mention the importance of the number of lymph nodes examined and number positive, and explicitly link perineural and vascular invasion to higher recurrence risk.
criterion_scores.justification: It stresses the number examined and number positive (and lymph node ratio) and states LVI and PNI are common and increase recurrence risk.

criterion_scores.description: The response must mention tumor location (head, body, tail) as required for accurate pathologic staging (pT), and reference the AJCC staging system using pT, pN, pM nomenclature.
criterion_scores.justification: It specifies location (head/uncinate, neck, body, tail) and references AJCC 8th edition with pTNM/ypTNM nomenclature and details T/N/M criteria.

criterion_scores.description: The response recommends discussing the case with an oncologist to review the trial details and discuss the pros and cons.
criterion_scores.justification: While it suggests being co-managed at a high-volume center and posing questions to the trial team, it does not explicitly recommend discussing the case with an oncologist to review pros and cons.

criterion_scores.description: The response explains that there are no FDA-approved cancer vaccines for pancreatic cancer and that all vaccines for pancreatic cancer are experimental.
criterion_scores.justification: It states vaccines are experimental but does not explicitly state that there are no FDA-approved cancer vaccines for pancreatic cancer.

criterion_scores.description: The response explains how a cancer vaccine works.
criterion_scores.justification: It clearly explains that these are therapeutic vaccines intended to train the immune system to recognize tumor antigens.

criterion_scores.description: The response states clinical trials are how treatments are tested for diseases like pancreatic cancer.
criterion_scores.justification: Although it discusses trial phases and endpoints, it does not explicitly state that clinical trials are how treatments are tested.

criterion_scores.description: The response explains the four phases of clinical trials.
criterion_scores.justification: It references trial phases but does not explain Phase I–IV.

criterion_scores.description: The response recommends researching clinical trials prior to enrolling.
criterion_scores.justification: It provides extensive guidance on evaluating fit, key questions, and verifying legitimacy before enrolling.

criterion_scores.description: The response recommends ClinicalTrials.gov as a resource.
criterion_scores.justification: ClinicalTrials.gov is explicitly recommended with search tips.

criterion_scores.description: The response states patients should consider all of their treatment options prior to enrolling in a clinical trial.
criterion_scores.justification: It advises ensuring the trial does not delay or replace effective standard treatments and discusses standard therapy timing, implying consideration of all options.

criterion_scores.description: The response states clinical trials are designed to minimize patient harm and closely follow ethical standards.
criterion_scores.justification: Safety plans are mentioned, but there is no explicit statement about minimizing harm and adherence to ethical standards.

criterion_scores.description: The response reviews potential benefits and risks of clinical trial participation.
criterion_scores.justification: It lists potential benefits and a thorough set of risks, including side effects and practical burdens.

criterion_scores.description: The response recommends discussing with the clinical trial research team about costs to the patient for participating in the trial.
criterion_scores.justification: It explicitly suggests asking what the sponsor covers versus insurance and about travel/lodging stipends.

criterion_scores.description: The response must explicitly mention that vaccine clinical trials in pancreatic cancer are designed to address the poor response of this malignancy to standard immunotherapy.
criterion_scores.justification: It notes pancreatic cancer is immunologically 'cold' and hard to treat with immunotherapy, but does not explicitly state that vaccine trials are designed to address this poor response.

criterion_scores.description: The response must explicitly mention that vaccine trials aim to stimulate tumor-specific T cell (immune cell) responses to enhance the immune system’s effectiveness in killing cancer.
criterion_scores.justification: It states vaccines train the immune system to recognize tumor antigens and that personalized vaccines can trigger strong T-cell responses, aligning with the criterion.

criterion_scores.description: The response must mention at least two of the following vaccine platforms: peptide-based vaccines targeting defined tumor antigens, dendritic cell vaccines loaded with tumor lysates, or personalized mRNA/neoantigen vaccines that encode patient-specific tumor mutations.
criterion_scores.justification: It mentions KRAS-targeted peptide vaccines, dendritic cell vaccines, and personalized neoantigen/mRNA vaccines.

criterion_scores.description: The response must mention that safety data from recent trials indicate that most vaccine regimens are well-tolerated, with adverse events generally limited to mild-to-moderate injection site reactions, flu-like symptoms, or transient fever.
criterion_scores.justification: Side effects are listed, but it does not attribute them to safety data from recent trials nor state that most regimens are well-tolerated.

criterion_scores.description: The response must mention that most data on vaccine trials in pancreatic cancer are derived from early-phase studies with small sample sizes and limited long-term follow-up.
criterion_scores.justification: It states results come from small, early-phase trials but does not mention limited long-term follow-up.

criterion_scores.description: The response must explicitly define clinical trials as research studies that explore whether a new medical strategy, treatment, or device is safe and effective for humans.
criterion_scores.justification: No explicit definition of clinical trials is provided.

criterion_scores.description: The response must explicitly state that clinical trials are essential for optimizing current and future therapies for cancer.
criterion_scores.justification: The response does not explicitly state that clinical trials are essential for optimizing current and future cancer therapies.

criterion_scores.description: The response must mention that the patient will be informed, verbally and in writing, if a placebo is part of a clinical trial before they enroll.
criterion_scores.justification: It asks about randomization and the possibility of a placebo but does not state that patients will be informed verbally and in writing prior to enrollment.

criterion_scores.description: The response explicitly recommends discussing care coordination concerns directly with the patient’s oncologist.
criterion_scores.justification: The response advises naming a single 'quarterback' for care and states this is usually the medical oncologist, with instructions to confirm all updates route through that person and to include the oncologist in a care conference, which constitutes explicit direction to address coordination with the oncologist.

criterion_scores.description: The response clearly states that the medical oncologist typically serves as the coordinating physician among the different specialists on the healthcare team.
criterion_scores.justification: It states, 'For most patients this is the medical oncologist' when naming the overall care quarterback, meeting the criterion.

criterion_scores.description: The response explicitly recommends discussing care coordination with a patient navigator or social worker.
criterion_scores.justification: It says 'Request an oncology nurse navigator or care coordinator' and 'Meet the oncology social worker,' explicitly recommending their involvement in coordination.

criterion_scores.description: The response states that most oncology clinics have nurses who specialize in helping patients coordinate care.
criterion_scores.justification: While it recommends requesting an oncology nurse navigator and notes 'If your center doesn’t assign one,' it does not explicitly state that most clinics have specialized nurses for coordination.

criterion_scores.description: The response explicitly recommends trying to schedule multiple appointments on one day to limit life interruptions.
criterion_scores.justification: It states, 'Cluster appointments on the same day when possible,' which directly satisfies this criterion.

criterion_scores.description: The response states that the different specialists will communicate with one another and document their assessments in the electronic medical record.
criterion_scores.justification: The response encourages signing HIPAA releases and provider-to-provider handoffs and asks imaging centers to push scans, but it does not explicitly state that specialists will document their assessments in the EMR.

criterion_scores.description: The response explicitly recommends asking about a multidisciplinary meeting with the involved specialists, sometimes called a “Tumor Board.”
criterion_scores.justification: It clearly states, 'Request tumor board review if not already done,' fulfilling the requirement.

criterion_scores.description: The response must explicitly mention a structured multidisciplinary approach for coordinating care among multiple specialists for pancreatic cancer.
criterion_scores.justification: It includes a section titled 'Leverage a multidisciplinary approach' and outlines coordinated involvement of multiple disciplines and formal structures (tumor board, care conferences), explicitly addressing structured multidisciplinary coordination.

criterion_scores.description: The response must list all required specialists: surgical oncology, medical oncology, radiation oncology, gastroenterology, genetics, nutrition, and palliative care, and mention their distinct roles in diagnosis, staging, treatment, and supportive care.
criterion_scores.justification: Although it mentions medical oncology, surgery, radiation oncology, genetics counselor, dietitian (nutrition), and palliative care, it does not explicitly list gastroenterology as a specialist nor describe distinct roles for each required specialist in diagnosis, staging, treatment, and supportive care.

criterion_scores.description: The response must emphasize the necessity of clear patient-centered communication.
criterion_scores.justification: It strongly emphasizes patient-centered communication through structured visit agendas, clarifying goals and next steps, defining points of contact and response times, and documenting values and priorities under 'Keep goals of care visible.'

criterion_scores.description: The response recommends discussing this with the patient’s oncologist.
criterion_scores.justification: Explicitly advises calling the oncology team urgently and building an emergency plan with the care team; asks for a 24/7 oncology contact and written plans.

criterion_scores.description: The response reviews common medical emergencies experienced by patients with pancreatic cancer, including biliary obstruction and bowel obstruction.
criterion_scores.justification: Lists multiple emergencies including infection/sepsis, biliary obstruction/cholangitis, and bowel/gastric outlet obstruction, with associated symptoms.

criterion_scores.description: The response recommends having an Advance Directive or Living Will in place to guide the patient’s care if they are unable to speak for themselves.
criterion_scores.justification: Specifically recommends discussing and keeping copies of advance directives/POLST and code status.

criterion_scores.description: The response recommends seeking help from a professional in talking about these challenging questions, like a social worker, spiritual worker, or palliative care professional.
criterion_scores.justification: Recommends early palliative care and/or hospice for 24/7 support and crisis management.

criterion_scores.description: The response recommends ensuring supportive care medications are refilled for symptoms like pain and nausea.
criterion_scores.justification: Advises keeping prescribed rescue meds (short-acting pain meds, anti-nausea meds, bowel regimen, naloxone) on hand and provides dosing plan guidance.

criterion_scores.description: The response must state that pancreatic cancer patients are at high risk for acute emergencies due to tumor progression, treatment effects, or comorbidities.
criterion_scores.justification: States that pancreatic cancer can come with sudden complications and details emergencies arising from tumor (biliary obstruction), treatments/devices (chemo, ports, opioids), and comorbidities (diabetes), establishing high risk from these causes.

criterion_scores.description: The response must mention that biliary obstruction presents with jaundice, dark urine, and pruritus.
criterion_scores.justification: Lists biliary obstruction/cholangitis symptoms including jaundice, dark urine, pale stools, itching, and RUQ pain.

criterion_scores.description: The response must describe gastric outlet obstruction as persistent vomiting, inability to tolerate oral intake, and abdominal distension.
criterion_scores.justification: Describes gastric outlet/bowel obstruction as persistent vomiting, belly swelling (distension), and separately flags inability to keep fluids down >12 hours.

criterion_scores.description: The response must mention VTE and include symptoms like sudden leg swelling, pain, shortness of breath, or chest pain, and state that pulmonary embolism is a leading cause of death after cancer itself.
criterion_scores.justification: Mentions DVT/PE with leg swelling/pain, dyspnea, chest pain, and hemoptysis, but does not state that PE is a leading cause of death after cancer itself.

criterion_scores.description: The response must mention febrile neutropenia as a life-threatening complication of chemotherapy, characterized by fever and signs of infection in the context of neutropenia.
criterion_scores.justification: Flags fever ≥100.4°F (especially during/after chemo) as an emergency, emphasizes early antibiotics, and instructs to alert triage about neutropenia risk, conveying life-threatening febrile neutropenia even if the exact term is not used.

criterion_scores.description: The response must mention metabolic derangements such as hypercalcemia (confusion, weakness, constipation) or hyponatremia (confusion, seizures).
criterion_scores.justification: Does not mention hypercalcemia or hyponatremia or their characteristic symptoms.

criterion_scores.description: The response must describe bowel obstruction as presenting with abdominal pain, vomiting, and constipation.
criterion_scores.justification: Notes bowel obstruction signs including pain, vomiting, and no gas/stools (constipation), and advises urgent evaluation.

criterion_scores.description: The response must mention spinal cord compression and its symptoms, such as new-onset weakness, sensory changes, or loss of bowel/bladder control.
criterion_scores.justification: Explicitly lists spinal cord compression with leg weakness, numbness, and loss of bowel/bladder control.

criterion_scores.description: The response recommends discussing the hearing changes with his oncologist or healthcare team immediately.
criterion_scores.justification: Explicitly advises to let the oncology team know promptly and to call his oncology team to review medications.

criterion_scores.description: The response states some chemotherapy treatments, like oxaliplatin, which is frequently used in treating pancreatic cancer as part of combination chemotherapy, can cause hearing changes.
criterion_scores.justification: Mentions oxaliplatin (used in FOLFIRINOX) and notes it can cause tinnitus and high-frequency hearing loss.

criterion_scores.description: The response states that platinum-based chemotherapy, such as cisplatin, is well-known to cause hearing loss (ototoxicity).
criterion_scores.justification: States that cisplatin carries the strongest risk and that platinum agents can cause ototoxicity.

criterion_scores.description: The response states the hearing changes may be related to other conditions like fatigue, infection, dehydration, malnutrition, or metabolic abnormalities from the cancer or its treatment.
criterion_scores.justification: Lists infections, dehydration, kidney problems, severe anemia, ear-wax blockage, and congestion as possible causes, addressing non-chemotherapy contributors.

criterion_scores.description: The response states it is important for the patient’s oncologist to know about new symptoms because they may need to adjust the dose of the chemotherapy or consider a different treatment.
criterion_scores.justification: Notes that the team may adjust doses, change drugs, or pause therapy if hearing issues are linked to treatment.

criterion_scores.description: The response states that treatment-related side effects may become worse or permanent if changes are not made to the treatment.
criterion_scores.justification: Does not explicitly state that ototoxicity may worsen or become permanent without treatment changes; only mentions some medication effects may be reversible if stopped.

criterion_scores.description: The response states hearing changes may be related to cancer spreading to the brain if there are other neurologic symptoms.
criterion_scores.justification: Specifically mentions brain/temporal bone metastasis and highlights neurologic red flags.

criterion_scores.description: The response states the hearing changes may be related to normal age-related hearing loss.
criterion_scores.justification: No mention of age-related (presbycusis) hearing loss.

criterion_scores.description: The response should mention that the risk of hearing loss increases with cumulative doses and patient age.
criterion_scores.justification: Mentions increased risk with cumulative dose and other factors (kidney problems, dehydration) but does not mention patient age.

criterion_scores.description: The response should mention that other therapies, including aminoglycoside antibiotics, loop diuretics, and radiation to the head/neck, can also contribute to hearing loss.
criterion_scores.justification: Mentions aminoglycosides and loop diuretics but does not mention radiation to the head/neck.

criterion_scores.description: The response should mention that referral for audiologic evaluation is advised.
criterion_scores.justification: Advises requesting an audiology evaluation (baseline and follow-up) and considering ENT referral.

criterion_scores.description: The response states proton therapy is a type of radiation therapy.
criterion_scores.justification: Explicitly states it is a type of external radiation that uses protons instead of X-rays.

criterion_scores.description: The response states proton therapy uses protons rather than photons to deliver highly conformal radiation doses to tumors.
criterion_scores.justification: Clearly contrasts protons with photons and describes dose deposition (Bragg peak) enabling conformality.

criterion_scores.description: The response states proton therapy may be more precise in its target field compared to traditional radiation therapy techniques, which may reduce treatment-related side effects.
criterion_scores.justification: Explains Bragg peak leading to reduced dose to nearby organs and lists potential reductions in side effects (nausea, ulcers, bleeding).

criterion_scores.description: The response states proton therapy is a safe and feasible option for select patients with locally advanced or recurrent pancreatic cancer, especially when minimizing toxicity to surrounding organs is critical.
criterion_scores.justification: Notes it can be an option after induction chemotherapy for locally advanced/unresectable disease and in re-irradiation, particularly when bowel/stomach dose constraints are limiting; cites guidelines endorsing select use.

criterion_scores.description: The response states the decision to use proton therapy is influenced by the cancer’s stage, location, size, proximity to other organs, among others.
criterion_scores.justification: Discusses use by stage (borderline resectable, unresectable), re-irradiation status, and proximity to duodenum/stomach; indicates case selection and constraints drive decisions.

criterion_scores.description: The response recommends discussing this with a Radiation Oncologist.
criterion_scores.justification: Provides a list of 'Good questions to ask the radiation oncologist,' clearly directing discussion with a Radiation Oncologist.

criterion_scores.description: The response recommends discussing this with the patient’s oncologist.
criterion_scores.justification: Does not explicitly recommend discussing with the (medical) oncologist; references 'her team' but specifically lists questions for the radiation oncologist only.

criterion_scores.description: The response states proton therapy has proven benefit in some cancers, like head and neck cancer, though has unclear benefit over traditional radiation therapy and is considered experimental in most types of cancer.
criterion_scores.justification: Notes lack of definitive survival advantage over photons and mentions trials, but does not cite proven benefit in other cancers (e.g., head and neck) nor label it experimental in most cancers.

criterion_scores.description: The response states not all cancer centers have the capability to provide proton therapy.
criterion_scores.justification: States there is a limited number of proton centers and discusses insurance pre-authorization.

criterion_scores.description: The response states proton therapy still carries the risk of side effects.
criterion_scores.justification: Provides a detailed section on common and serious side effects and notes these risks exist with any abdominal radiation.

criterion_scores.description: The response states proton therapy is often used in combination with chemotherapy (such as gemcitabine) as part of concurrent chemoradiation protocols.
criterion_scores.justification: States radiation is often given concurrently with low-dose 5-FU or capecitabine; also references systemic regimens like FOLFIRINOX or gemcitabine/nab-paclitaxel given before radiation.

criterion_scores.description: The response states proton therapy can be used for locally advanced, unresectable, or recurrent disease.
criterion_scores.justification: Explicitly mentions use in locally advanced/unresectable disease and re-irradiation for local recurrence.

criterion_scores.description: The response recommends discussing this with the patient’s healthcare team or oncologist, as they likely have financial experts who are knowledgeable in this area.
criterion_scores.justification: Explicitly advises working with the oncology team, social worker, and financial navigator; suggests the team/specialty pharmacy can enroll in programs.

criterion_scores.description: The response recommends learning about the patient’s insurance plan, including out-of-pocket costs.
criterion_scores.justification: Asks for insurance type, suggests reviewing insurance benefits (medical vs pharmacy), mentions copays and SHIP counseling.

criterion_scores.description: The response states pharmaceutical companies have programs to help patients cover the cost of medications and provides examples.
criterion_scores.justification: Lists manufacturer assistance programs and specific examples (Abraxane, Lynparza, Keytruda, Tarceva, Creon) and notes free drug/copay help.

criterion_scores.description: The response states large hospital systems and cancer centers may have assistance programs.
criterion_scores.justification: Mentions hospital/clinic resources, 340B pricing, charity care/discounts, and in-network infusion site options.

criterion_scores.description: The response states patient assistance programs may cover all or most of the cost of medications for cancer patients.
criterion_scores.justification: Notes manufacturer programs can provide free drug (covers all) or copay help, implying most costs may be covered.

criterion_scores.description: The response states government programs may offer assistance with the cost of medications and provides examples.
criterion_scores.justification: Cites Medicare Part D Extra Help, Medicare Savings Programs, State Pharmaceutical Assistance Programs, and Medicaid.

criterion_scores.description: The response offers examples of non-profit organizations with patient assistance programs.
criterion_scores.justification: Provides multiple non-profit examples: PAN Foundation, HealthWell, CancerCare, PAF Co-Pay Relief, The Assistance Fund, Good Days.

criterion_scores.description: The response offers examples of pancreatic cancer-specific patient assistance programs.
criterion_scores.justification: Specifically lists the Pancreatic Cancer Action Network (PanCAN) with phone number and services.

criterion_scores.description: The response recommends applying for assistance early as the process may take time and delay treatment.
criterion_scores.justification: Provides process tips and to apply to multiple funds but does not explicitly recommend applying early to avoid treatment delays.

criterion_scores.description: The response must mention federal, state, manufacturer, and independent charity options for medication cost assistance for pancreatic cancer patients.
criterion_scores.justification: Mentions federal (Medicare Extra Help), state (SPAP, Medicaid/SHIP), manufacturer programs, and independent charities (PAN, HealthWell, etc.).

criterion_scores.description: The response must explicitly state that Medicaid offers comprehensive prescription drug coverage with minimal co-payments and is the most effective public program for low-income patients.
criterion_scores.justification: Mentions Medicaid application and secondary coverage but does not explicitly state comprehensive coverage, minimal co-pays, or that it is the most effective program.

criterion_scores.description: The response must mention that manufacturer-sponsored assistance programs provide free or discounted medications to eligible uninsured or underinsured patients, requiring proof of financial hardship and doctor certification.
criterion_scores.justification: States free/copay help and that the oncology team can enroll, but does not explicitly mention required proof of financial hardship and physician certification.

criterion_scores.description: The response must specify that independent nonprofits like HealthWell and PAN Foundation offer co-pay and premium assistance to insured patients with incomes below 400-500% of the federal poverty level.
criterion_scores.justification: Lists HealthWell and PAN but does not state premium assistance or the 400–500% FPL income criteria for insured patients.

criterion_scores.description: The response must mention the complexity of accessing assistance programs and disparities among non-English speakers and some ethnic groups.
criterion_scores.justification: Notes fluctuating fund availability and process tips but does not discuss disparities for non-English speakers or specific ethnic groups.

criterion_scores.description: The response must mention financial navigators and online tools such as NeedyMeds or RxAssist.
criterion_scores.justification: Explicitly mentions financial navigators and includes NeedyMeds as an online tool.

criterion_scores.description: The response recommends discussing this with the patient’s oncologist.
criterion_scores.justification: The response explicitly prompts discussion with the oncologist by providing a section titled 'Good questions to ask the oncologist' and listing specific questions.

criterion_scores.description: The response states maintenance therapy is typically used in pancreatic cancer after the initial induction therapy.
criterion_scores.justification: It states maintenance is used after the first phase of chemotherapy when the cancer has responded or is stable, and specifies timing after ~4–6 months of first-line chemotherapy.

criterion_scores.description: The response states maintenance therapy typically involves fewer anti-cancer drugs with the goal of limiting side effects.
criterion_scores.justification: It describes de-escalation (e.g., dropping oxaliplatin or nab-paclitaxel) and explicitly notes goals of reducing side effects and preserving quality of life.

criterion_scores.description: The response states the oncologist will continue to monitor the cancer closely while the patient is on maintenance therapy.
criterion_scores.justification: It outlines monitoring with regular clinic visits, labs, imaging every 2–3 months, and CA 19-9 when appropriate.

criterion_scores.description: The response states that if the cancer grows while on maintenance therapy, combination therapy may be reintroduced to get the cancer back under control.
criterion_scores.justification: It mentions a 'stop-and-go' approach where drugs are re-added if the cancer grows again.

criterion_scores.description: The response states chemotherapy side effects are typically cumulative, so using maintenance therapy may help the patient tolerate treatment for a longer period of time.
criterion_scores.justification: It notes initiating maintenance when 'side effects are accumulating' and gives examples (avoiding neuropathy), implying cumulative toxicity and the rationale for improved tolerability over time.

criterion_scores.description: The response states maintenance therapy may involve chemotherapy, targeted therapy, or immunotherapy depending upon the characteristics of the patient’s tumor.
criterion_scores.justification: It details de-escalated chemotherapy, PARP inhibitor maintenance for BRCA1/2 or PALB2, and immunotherapy for MSI-H/dMMR cases, tying choices to tumor genetics.

criterion_scores.description: The response should mention that the decision to initiate maintenance therapy should be individualized, considering disease response, cumulative toxicities, patient preference, and goals of care.
criterion_scores.justification: While it considers disease response and toxicities and suggests questions for shared decision-making, it does not explicitly state that the decision should be individualized to patient preference and goals of care.

criterion_scores.description: The response recommends discussing this with the patient’s oncologist.
criterion_scores.justification: It explicitly says to tell the oncology team about the anxiety and to ask for referrals and a palliative care consult.

criterion_scores.description: The response recommends discussing this with a licensed mental health care provider.
criterion_scores.justification: It recommends referrals to a psycho-oncologist or oncology social worker and suggests finding a psycho-oncologist/therapist.

criterion_scores.description: The response instructs the patient to seek immediate medical evaluation if they are experiencing thoughts of harming themselves or others.
criterion_scores.justification: It provides immediate crisis resources (988 Suicide & Crisis Lifeline) and advises using them if anyone feels unsafe or overwhelmed, which covers urgent risk scenarios.

criterion_scores.description: The response states anxiety is a common occurrence in patients with cancer.
criterion_scores.justification: It states, “Treatment anxiety is common and manageable.”

criterion_scores.description: The response states treatments like cognitive behavioral therapy may help to control anxiety.
criterion_scores.justification: It lists CBT as an evidence-based therapy, along with ACT and MBSR.

criterion_scores.description: The response states medications may help to control anxiety.
criterion_scores.justification: It advises asking whether medication or adjusting current meds might reduce anxiety.

criterion_scores.description: The response must explicitly mention psychotherapy, psychoeducation, supportive therapy, and integrative modalities as available resources for treatment-related anxiety.
criterion_scores.justification: While it mentions integrative therapies (mindfulness, yoga, acupuncture) and therapists, it does not explicitly use the terms “psychotherapy,” “psychoeducation,” or “supportive therapy.”

criterion_scores.description: The response must explicitly mention mindfulness-based interventions or mindfulness-based stress reduction.
criterion_scores.justification: It explicitly mentions mindfulness-based stress reduction (MBSR) and provides mindfulness resources.

criterion_scores.description: The response recommends mindfulness and relaxation techniques.
criterion_scores.justification: It recommends 4-7-8 breathing, grounding, mindfulness, and relaxation apps/resources.

criterion_scores.description: The response offers pancreatic cancer-specific resources.
criterion_scores.justification: It lists PanCAN, NPF, Let’s Win!, Lustgarten Foundation, and Smart Patients (pancreatic cancer community).

criterion_scores.description: The response offers mental health-specific resources.
criterion_scores.justification: It includes CancerCare (counseling), Cancer Support Community, ADAA directory, and Psychology Today therapist finder.

criterion_scores.description: The response recommends participation in cancer support groups.
criterion_scores.justification: It advises asking the center about support groups and references Cancer Support Community and CancerCare groups, including caregiver-specific groups.

criterion_scores.description: The response recommends discussing this with the patient’s oncologist.
criterion_scores.justification: It advises evaluation at a high-volume pancreatic cancer center with a multidisciplinary team including medical and radiation oncology and provides specific questions to ask his team, clearly directing discussion with the oncology team.

criterion_scores.description: The response states cryotherapy is a procedure that uses metal instruments cooled to subzero temperatures in order to kill tumors.
criterion_scores.justification: It explains that a thin probe is used and very cold gas creates an ice ball that kills cancer cells, conveying the subzero-cooled instrument mechanism even though it does not explicitly say 'metal.'

criterion_scores.description: The response should mention that cryotherapy (also called cryoablation) is a minimally invasive locoregional treatment that destroys tumor tissue by freezing it, typically using probes inserted through the skin (percutaneously) or intraoperatively under imaging guidance.
criterion_scores.justification: It explicitly calls it cryotherapy/cryoablation, describes tissue destruction by freezing, and details probe placement routes (surgical, percutaneous, experimental EUS) under imaging guidance, which reflects a minimally invasive locoregional approach.

criterion_scores.description: The response states the decision to use cryotherapy involves the cancer’s size, location, proximity to other organs, among other things.
criterion_scores.justification: It notes risk depends on tumor location and size and emphasizes protecting nearby structures, indicating these factors influence candidacy.

criterion_scores.description: The response recommends discussing the benefits and risks of this procedure with the patient’s healthcare team.
criterion_scores.justification: Under 'Questions to ask his team,' it specifically includes discussing the realistic benefits, risks, and recovery time.

criterion_scores.description: The response states cryotherapy may be used in conjunction with other treatment modalities like chemotherapy.
criterion_scores.justification: It explicitly states it can be combined with chemotherapy.

criterion_scores.description: The response states cryotherapy is not typically used to cure cancer but may be used to debulk tumors that are not operable.
criterion_scores.justification: It emphasizes non-curative, palliative use in pancreatic adenocarcinoma, describes local tumor control/shrinkage for people who cannot have surgery, aligning with debulking intent.

criterion_scores.description: The response states not all patients benefit from cryotherapy.
criterion_scores.justification: It restricts consideration to select patients (cannot have surgery, disease confined to the pancreas) and notes limited evidence with no proven survival benefit, implying that not all patients benefit.

criterion_scores.description: The response should mention that in pancreatic cancer, cryotherapy is not a standard first-line therapy but is considered for patients with unresectable, locally advanced, or metastatic disease who are not candidates for surgical resection or have failed systemic therapy.
criterion_scores.justification: It states it is not a standard option, considered mainly in trials/palliative settings for those who cannot have surgery with borderline/locally advanced disease, and that it is rarely used in metastatic disease.

criterion_scores.description: The response should mention that its primary role is palliative, aiming to reduce tumor burden, alleviate pain, and potentially improve quality of life and local disease control.
criterion_scores.justification: It explicitly frames use as palliative in pancreatic adenocarcinoma and lists goals including shrinking/controlling the tumor locally and relieving pain/obstruction, consistent with QoL improvement and local disease control.

criterion_scores.description: The response recommends discussing this with the patient’s oncologist.
criterion_scores.justification: Explicitly advises to discuss items with the oncology team and doctors (e.g., 'Practical takeaways to discuss with the oncology team,' 'ask about ctDNA monitoring,' 'Ensure germline genetic testing ...').

criterion_scores.description: The response states CA 19-9 is the tumor marker most commonly used to track disease status in pancreatic cancer.
criterion_scores.justification: Clearly states 'CA 19-9 is the most commonly used tumor marker in pancreatic ductal adenocarcinoma (PDAC)'.

criterion_scores.description: The response states other tumor markers, like CEA and CA 125, are less reliable than CA 19-9 for disease monitoring in pancreatic cancer and are used more frequently in other gastrointestinal or genitourinary cancers.
criterion_scores.justification: Mentions CEA has lower sensitivity than CA19-9, but does not state they are used more frequently in other GI or GU cancers; thus requirement not fully met.

criterion_scores.description: The response states tumor markers may be used to monitor the course of disease in patients with pancreatic cancer, along with imaging studies.
criterion_scores.justification: States markers are best used alongside imaging and clinical assessment and emphasizes using trends with imaging and symptoms.

criterion_scores.description: The response states tumor markers are not reliable markers of disease in all patients with pancreatic cancer, as not all tumors secrete the markers.
criterion_scores.justification: Notes limitations (e.g., Lewis antigen–negative patients, biliary obstruction) and that none are perfect; conveys unreliability across all patients.

criterion_scores.description: The response states circulating tumor DNA (ctDNA) is an emerging technology aimed at detecting early cancer progression and recurrence.
criterion_scores.justification: Describes ctDNA as detecting tumor mutations and sometimes detecting progression earlier than scans; identifies it as not yet routine.

criterion_scores.description: The response states circulating tumor DNA (ctDNA) is not FDA approved for disease monitoring in pancreatic cancer and remains experimental.
criterion_scores.justification: Does not mention FDA approval status or that ctDNA remains experimental; only notes it is not yet routine.

criterion_scores.description: The response should mention that CEA is elevated in 30-60% of pancreatic cancer cases and is particularly useful in Lewis-negative patients who do not secrete CA19-9.
criterion_scores.justification: Mentions usefulness of CEA in Lewis-negative patients but does not provide the 30–60% elevation statistic required by the criterion.

criterion_scores.description: The response should mention that both CEA and CA125 have demonstrated value for diagnosis, prognosis, and monitoring, especially when CA19-9 is not informative. CA125, when combined with CA19-9, improves diagnostic accuracy and is associated with tumor burden and metastatic disease.
criterion_scores.justification: Notes prognostic/monitoring roles and correlation with metastatic burden, and that panels exist, but does not explicitly state diagnostic value nor that CA125 + CA19-9 improves diagnostic accuracy.

criterion_scores.description: The response should mention that emerging markers such as LAMC2, POSTN are not yet standard in routine clinical practice.
criterion_scores.justification: Does not mention LAMC2 or POSTN; only discusses other emerging assays (cfDNA methylation, exosomes) as research-stage.

criterion_scores.description: The response states that hand-foot syndrome is a common side effect of some chemotherapy drugs used to treat pancreatic cancer, including capecitabine and 5-FU.
criterion_scores.justification: Explicitly notes HFS is common with pancreatic cancer regimens, specifically naming capecitabine and continuous-infusion 5-FU.

criterion_scores.description: The response recommends discussing this with the patient’s oncologist and healthcare team immediately.
criterion_scores.justification: Advises telling the oncology team promptly and describes clinical actions they may take.

criterion_scores.description: The response states that the patient’s oncologist may recommend reducing the chemotherapy dose.
criterion_scores.justification: States chemotherapy may be held and restarted at a reduced dose after improvement.

criterion_scores.description: The response instructs the patient to seek immediate medical evaluation if the patient experiences fever, chills, blisters, or pus draining from the affected area.
criterion_scores.justification: Advises urgent care for fever and pus, and separately flags blisters as an urgent concern; although chills are not mentioned, the response clearly instructs immediate evaluation for key warning signs.

criterion_scores.description: The response states the patient’s oncology team will grade the severity of the hand-foot syndrome, which will determine the recommended treatment.
criterion_scores.justification: Provides grade 1–3 severity definitions and corresponding management steps.

criterion_scores.description: The response recommends hand hygiene with a gentle soap.
criterion_scores.justification: Mentions lukewarm water and moisturizing after washing but does not recommend using a gentle soap.

criterion_scores.description: The response states pain may be controlled with over-the-counter medications like Tylenol or ibuprofen, though the patient should check with their healthcare team first.
criterion_scores.justification: Recommends acetaminophen and advises checking with oncology before using NSAIDs like ibuprofen.

criterion_scores.description: The response states oral or topical prescription pain medications may be needed if pain is severe.
criterion_scores.justification: Notes stronger pain medicines may be needed and suggests topical lidocaine for focal pain.

criterion_scores.description: The response recommends utilizing topical moisturizers.
criterion_scores.justification: Recommends frequent use of thick creams/ointments (e.g., urea, petroleum jelly, lanolin).

criterion_scores.description: The response recommends skin protection with loose clothing and soft shoe soles.
criterion_scores.justification: Advises cushioned socks, soft insoles, and roomy shoes but does not mention loose clothing.

criterion_scores.description: The response recommends cooling the skin with cold compresses.
criterion_scores.justification: Specifically recommends cool soaks or cold packs for 10–15 minutes several times daily.

criterion_scores.description: The response recommends avoiding hot showers and activities that cause rubbing on the skin.
criterion_scores.justification: Advises avoiding hot water and limiting friction-inducing activities such as long walks, running, and heavy gripping.

criterion_scores.description: The response should mention that prevention strategies include celecoxib and urea cream.
criterion_scores.justification: Mentions urea cream for prevention but does not mention celecoxib.

criterion_scores.description: The response should mention that cooling procedures, such as frozen gloves or socks applied during taxane infusions, may prevent or reduce HFS severity and are recommended by the Oncology Nursing Society for taxane-based regimens.
criterion_scores.justification: Refers generally to regional cooling during infusion but does not specify frozen gloves/socks during taxane infusions or ONS recommendations.

criterion_scores.description: The response should mention that prevention strategies such as Pyridoxine (vitamin B6) and lactic acid have not shown consistent benefit for prevention or treatment of HFS in randomized trials.
criterion_scores.justification: States pyridoxine has mixed evidence and is not routinely recommended but does not mention lactic acid.

criterion_scores.description: The response should mention that omeprazole (a proton pump inhibitor) and tipiracil (a thymidine phosphorylase inhibitor) may have prophylactic effects, but these are not yet standard practice.
criterion_scores.justification: No mention of omeprazole or tipiracil as potential prophylaxis.

criterion_scores.description: The response should mention that management of established HFS includes topical urea and corticosteroids.
criterion_scores.justification: Explicitly recommends topical corticosteroids and urea for affected areas.

criterion_scores.description: The response should mention that Photobiomodulation (low-level laser therapy) has shown promise as an adjunct for pain and symptom control.
criterion_scores.justification: Does not mention photobiomodulation or low-level laser therapy.

criterion_scores.description: The decision between a cancer center and community oncology is often based on the type and stage of cancer, the patient’s insurance, location, and preference.
criterion_scores.justification: The response clearly addresses type/stage (e.g., surgical candidacy, borderline resectable, unusual tumor types), and location/convenience (travel, parking, housing). It implies personal preference via shared care. However, it does not explicitly discuss the role of insurance or coverage in deciding between settings, which is a required element.

criterion_scores.description: Cancer centers may have access to more advanced therapies and clinical trials than community oncology programs.
criterion_scores.justification: Explicitly states cancer centers have more clinical trials, genomic tumor boards, advanced procedures, and specialized options; notes community sites have fewer trials but may partner for access.

criterion_scores.description: Pancreatic cancer requires multidisciplinary care involving medical oncology, radiation oncology, and surgical oncology, which may be more readily available at a large cancer center.
criterion_scores.justification: Directly emphasizes pancreas-focused multidisciplinary teams, regular tumor boards, and lists specialties (GI medical oncology, HPB surgery, radiation oncology, interventional endoscopy/radiology, pathology, genetics, nutrition, palliative care).

criterion_scores.description: Cancer centers may be more equipped to handle complex care for advanced disease.
criterion_scores.justification: Notes cancer centers handle complex scenarios (biliary/duodenal obstruction, advanced endoscopy, difficult pain control), specialized radiation (SBRT), and coordinated neoadjuvant strategies—indicating greater capacity for complex care.

criterion_scores.description: Community oncology programs may be more convenient and closer to home.
criterion_scores.justification: States community practices are closer to home, with easier scheduling and convenience for frequent labs/infusions; highlights reduced travel burden.

criterion_scores.description: There may be differences in cost between cancer centers and community oncology programs based on the patient’s insurance.
criterion_scores.justification: While the response mentions out-of-pocket travel costs, financial counseling, and asks about "out-of-pocket costs," it does not explicitly address how insurance coverage or network differences impact cost between settings.

criterion_scores.description: Cancer centers may offer more support services to patients.
criterion_scores.justification: Lists robust support services at cancer centers: genetics, nutrition, pain/symptom specialists (e.g., celiac plexus block), social work, financial counseling, housing help.

criterion_scores.description: Most standard cancer care can be delivered at community oncology programs.
criterion_scores.justification: Clearly states community oncology often does standard systemic therapy well (FOLFIRINOX, gemcitabine/nab-paclitaxel, NALIRIFOX), toxicity management, labs, transfusions, growth factor support, and palliative care.

criterion_scores.description: Cancer centers include NCI-designated comprehensive cancer centers and academic medical centers.
criterion_scores.justification: Explicitly references high-volume academic centers and NCI-designated cancer centers, and mentions NCCN Member Institutions.

criterion_scores.description: Cancer centers are often located in major cities, which can mean longer travel times, more complex scheduling, and larger, busier environments.
criterion_scores.justification: Addresses longer travel, parking, housing burdens, and longer visits at major centers; implies more complex logistics even if not explicitly stating "major cities."

criterion_scores.description: In some cases, initial treatment planning can be done at a cancer center, and follow-up care can be done at a community center closer to home.
criterion_scores.justification: Proposes a "shared care" plan: initial/second-opinion at a high-volume center to set strategy and trial review, chemotherapy locally, and returning to the center for milestones and telemedicine check-ins.

criterion_scores.description: The response recommends discussing this with the patient’s healthcare team.
criterion_scores.justification: The response repeatedly advises involving the care team: it references waiting for the surgeon’s clearance, asking the care team for guidance based on ANC/platelets, and explicitly says to ask the oncologist or oncology nurse about sexual side effects and referrals.

criterion_scores.description: The response states patients undergoing treatment for pancreatic cancer may experience a decrease in libido related to symptoms from treatment or the cancer itself, like fatigue, nausea, pain, malnutrition, anxiety, and depression.
criterion_scores.justification: It explicitly notes cancer/treatment can affect desire and mentions causes such as fatigue, pain, medications (opioids/antidepressants), and anxiety/distress. While not all listed examples are named (e.g., nausea, malnutrition), it clearly links decreased desire/libido to treatment-related symptoms.

criterion_scores.description: The response specifically mentions at least one of the following changes in intimacy: decreased desire, arousal disorders, pain, erectile dysfunction, altered body image, or emotional distress.
criterion_scores.justification: It mentions decreased desire, erectile difficulties, pain/discomfort, altered body image, and emotional distress related to sex and body image.

criterion_scores.description: The response recommends open communication.
criterion_scores.justification: It encourages ongoing check-ins (e.g., green/yellow/red), a pause word, and provides a conversation starter, all emphasizing open communication.

criterion_scores.description: The response recommends seeking input from a professional trained in intimacy problems.
criterion_scores.justification: It recommends referral to a sexual medicine specialist, pelvic floor physical therapist, and a certified sex therapist—professionals trained to address intimacy problems.

criterion_scores.description: The response recommends cancer support groups.
criterion_scores.justification: No explicit recommendation for cancer support groups is provided.

criterion_scores.description: The response explicitly mentions at least one of the following interventions: psychosocial therapy, psychosexual therapy, or couples-based therapy.
criterion_scores.justification: Although it mentions sex therapists and social workers, it does not explicitly name psychosocial therapy, psychosexual therapy, or couples-based therapy.

criterion_scores.description: The response explicitly mentions at least one of the following referral options: medical sexologist, psycho-sexologist, social worker, or psychologist.
criterion_scores.justification: It explicitly suggests referral to an oncology social worker and a sexual medicine specialist (aligned with a medical sexologist).

criterion_scores.description: The response explicitly states that concerns about intimacy during treatment for a loved one with pancreatic cancer are common.
criterion_scores.justification: The opening states it is very common for cancer and its treatments to affect desire, comfort, and confidence, normalizing these concerns.

criterion_scores.description: The response defines radiofrequency ablation.
criterion_scores.justification: Clearly defines RFA as a probe delivering alternating electrical current to heat tissue (60–100°C) to destroy targeted cells; distinguishes it from chemotherapy.

criterion_scores.description: The response states radiofrequency ablation is minimally invasive and typically does not require surgery.
criterion_scores.justification: Explains RFA is performed percutaneously or via endoscopic ultrasound and only sometimes during surgery; notes same-day/overnight stays, indicating a minimally invasive, typically non-surgical approach.

criterion_scores.description: The response recommends discussing this with the patient’s healthcare team.
criterion_scores.justification: Provides a dedicated 'What to ask the doctors' section, explicitly encouraging discussion with the care team.

criterion_scores.description: The response states not all patients with pancreatic cancer benefit from radiofrequency ablation.
criterion_scores.justification: States RFA is not standard curative therapy for PDAC, hasn’t shown clear survival benefit, and effectiveness depends on tumor factors, implying not all patients benefit.

criterion_scores.description: The response considers the potential risks and benefits of radiofrequency ablation for the treatment of pancreatic cancer.
criterion_scores.justification: Clearly lists benefits (local control, symptom relief, bile duct patency, pNETs) and detailed risks/complications with approximate rates.

criterion_scores.description: The response states radiofrequency ablation is typically used in a multidisciplinary treatment plan along with chemotherapy for the treatment of pancreatic cancer.
criterion_scores.justification: Notes systemic chemotherapy as the backbone, discusses integration with radiation and other modalities, and addresses coordination with chemotherapy timeline.

criterion_scores.description: The response states radiofrequency ablation is a procedure performed by specially trained Interventional Radiologists.
criterion_scores.justification: Does not explicitly state that Interventional Radiologists perform RFA; mentions approaches (EUS, percutaneous, surgical) without naming operator specialty.

criterion_scores.description: The response states this is typically an outpatient procedure.
criterion_scores.justification: Says EUS/percutaneous RFA is often same day or 1-night stay, conveying typical outpatient management.

criterion_scores.description: The response should mention that in pancreatic cancer, RFA is most commonly delivered via endoscopic ultrasound guidance (EUS-RFA), allowing precise targeting of the tumor while minimizing injury to surrounding structures.
criterion_scores.justification: States it is more commonly done via EUS-RFA and describes EUS guidance for probe placement; planning around ducts/vessels implies precision and safety.

criterion_scores.description: The response should mention that radiofrequency ablation is used in pancreatic cancer primarily for unresectable or inoperable tumors as a palliative or adjunctive therapy.
criterion_scores.justification: Explicitly mentions use for tumors that can’t be surgically removed and for symptom relief, indicating palliative/adjunctive intent.

criterion_scores.description: The response should mention that RFA is not a substitute for surgery or systemic therapy in resectable disease.
criterion_scores.justification: States RFA is not standard curative therapy for PDAC and highlights chemotherapy ± radiation as the standard backbone, implying RFA does not replace surgery/systemic therapy in resectable cases.

criterion_scores.description: The response recommends discussing this with the patient’s healthcare team or oncologist.
criterion_scores.justification: Explicitly advises engaging the care team: recommends medication reconciliation with the oncology pharmacist or palliative care, bringing the med list to every visit and sharing with clinicians, asking the team about NSAID use, and provides urgent 'call the care team' triggers.

criterion_scores.description: The response states it is normal for patients with pancreatic cancer to be on multiple medications.
criterion_scores.justification: Clearly states, “It’s very common for people with pancreatic cancer to be on many medications,” indicating this is normal.

criterion_scores.description: The response states patients undergoing treatment for pancreatic cancer may need medications for symptom control, including acid reflux, nausea, pain, diarrhea, and enzyme replacement.
criterion_scores.justification: Lists PPIs for acid suppression (acid reflux), multiple antiemetics for nausea, analgesics/opioids for pain, loperamide for diarrhea, and pancreatic enzyme replacement (pancrelipase).

criterion_scores.description: The response recommends utilizing a pill organizer.
criterion_scores.justification: Explicit recommendation: “Use a weekly pill organizer and phone alarms.”

criterion_scores.description: The response recommends keeping an updated medication list with administration times.
criterion_scores.justification: Advises keeping an up-to-date med list including drug, dose, and when/why taken, which covers administration timing.

criterion_scores.description: The response recommends reviewing the patient’s medication list with the healthcare team to identify strategies to make handling the medications easier.
criterion_scores.justification: Recommends medication reconciliation with oncology pharmacist or palliative care and suggests discussing simplification (duplicates, timing), directly addressing strategies to make handling meds easier.

criterion_scores.description: The response recommends discussing yoga with the patient’s healthcare team.
criterion_scores.justification: Explicitly advises clearance by the oncology team: “when it’s…cleared by the oncology team” and “Have their oncology team clear them first.”

criterion_scores.description: The response states yoga may improve a cancer patient’s quality of life.
