criterion_scores.justification: It explicitly states that epigenetic silencing can switch off tumor-suppressor genes and gives the example of promoter hypermethylation turning off tumor-suppressor promoters.

criterion_scores.description: The response should state that epigenetic changes can lead to activation of oncogenes.
criterion_scores.justification: The response notes that epigenetic changes can "turn on growth programs" in cancer, which is equivalent to activating oncogenic pathways.

criterion_scores.description: The response should state that epigenetic changes can contribute to changes in the behavior of the tumor, such as increased propensity to spread.
criterion_scores.justification: It explicitly states epigenetic programs enable EMT, invasion, and metastasis, demonstrating altered tumor behavior and increased propensity to spread.

criterion_scores.description: The response should state that epigenetic changes can impact treatment response.
criterion_scores.justification: It explains that chromatin changes can induce drug-tolerant states leading to resistance and relapse, and discusses how reversing epigenetic silencing might restore drug sensitivity (investigational).

criterion_scores.description: The response should mention that targeting epigenetic changes in pancreatic cancer is an experimental topic that is being actively researched.
criterion_scores.justification: It states there is no established standard epigenetic therapy in PDAC, but it is an active research area with multiple epigenetic drugs in clinical trials and provides specific classes (DNMT, HDAC, BET, EZH2, etc.).

criterion_scores.description: Recommend considering accredited agencies with a good reputation.
criterion_scores.justification: Explicitly advises choosing agencies that are licensed, Medicare‑certified, and accredited (Joint Commission, CHAP, ACHC) and to check ratings on Medicare Care Compare.

criterion_scores.description: Recommend agencies that provide a broad range of services for evolving needs.
criterion_scores.justification: Details multiple service lines (skilled home health, non‑medical care, palliative, hospice) and emphasizes capabilities across pain, drains, nutrition, blood sugars, PT/OT, social work, and rapid escalation/transition to palliative or hospice.

criterion_scores.description: Recommend inquiring with oncology team about social work support to find covered home health care.
criterion_scores.justification: Directs the reader to ask the oncology clinic navigator or social worker to send referrals and to assist with comparing agencies and coverage.

criterion_scores.description: State that there is a broad range of in-home care types and that the family should consider their needed tasks.
criterion_scores.justification: Clearly outlines multiple in‑home care types (skilled home health, non‑medical care, palliative, hospice) and prompts preparation of a needs/goals summary, implying consideration of specific tasks.

criterion_scores.description: Summarize common assistance types (e.g., cooking, cleaning, home upkeep, shopping).
criterion_scores.justification: Lists non‑medical supports such as help with bathing, dressing, meals, errands, and companionship; these encompass common household and daily living assistance (meals/cooking, errands/shopping).

criterion_scores.description: Provide links to websites where patients can learn more about types of care.
criterion_scores.justification: Names resources (Medicare Care Compare, PanCAN, ACS, CancerCare) but does not include actual hyperlinks/URLs.

criterion_scores.description: Mention Hospice as in-home care for prognosis of 6 months or less.
criterion_scores.justification: Explicitly describes hospice at home for ~6‑month prognosis with focus on comfort and included services.

criterion_scores.description: State that home health includes skilled nursing and in-home therapies (PT/OT).
criterion_scores.justification: Defines home health (skilled) as including RN and PT/OT along with other disciplines.

criterion_scores.description: Explicitly seek agencies with oncology experience/oncology-trained staff.
criterion_scores.justification: Advises looking for strong oncology/palliative experience and specific oncology-related capabilities (pain, chemo safety, ports, biliary drains).

criterion_scores.description: The response should define angiogenesis.
criterion_scores.justification: Clearly defines angiogenesis as new blood vessel growth stimulated by tumors to supply oxygen and nutrients.

criterion_scores.description: The response should describe the role of angiogenesis in solid tumors.
criterion_scores.justification: Explains that many cancers rely on angiogenesis and that blocking it can slow growth and augment other treatments, capturing its general role in solid tumors.

criterion_scores.description: The response should describe the role of angiogenesis in pancreatic cancer.
criterion_scores.justification: Accurately contrasts PDAC (hypovascular, desmoplastic stroma, hypoxia, poor drug delivery) with pNETs (hypervascular and more angiogenesis-dependent).

criterion_scores.description: The response should discuss how angiogenesis is a target for cancer treatment in some cancers.
criterion_scores.justification: Notes that anti-angiogenic therapy can help in many cancers and specifies targeted options effective in pNETs (sunitinib, everolimus), demonstrating angiogenesis as a treatment target.

criterion_scores.description: The response should state that anti-angiogenesis drugs are not used routinely in pancreatic cancer as they have not been shown to significantly improve outcomes.
criterion_scores.justification: Explicitly states that anti-angiogenic drugs have not improved survival in PDAC, are not standard, and cites examples (bevacizumab, aflibercept, ramucirumab, VEGF TKIs) that failed to show benefit.

criterion_scores.description: The response should link to randomized control trials studying the effect of anti-angiogenic therapies in pancreatic cancer, with summaries.
criterion_scores.justification: Mentions that large trials were negative and lists agents but provides no specific trial names, links, or concise randomized trial summaries.

criterion_scores.description: The response should recommend that the patient discuss treatment options with their oncology team.
criterion_scores.justification: Encourages discussion with the oncology team, provides specific questions to ask, and invites sharing details to tailor guidance.

criterion_scores.description: The response should state that liver function is routinely monitored during treatment using labs.
criterion_scores.justification: Explicitly states baseline and regular (every 1–3 weeks) monitoring with liver blood tests (AST/ALT, ALP, GGT, bilirubin, albumin, INR) during therapy.

criterion_scores.description: The response should describe ways in which pancreatic cancer and pancreatic cancer treatment can affect the liver.
criterion_scores.justification: Covers bile duct obstruction from tumor, liver metastases, chemotherapy hepatotoxicity, immunotherapy hepatitis, radiation injury, TPN/antibiotic-related injury.

criterion_scores.description: The response should state that changes in liver function labs will often be investigated further with imaging studies.
criterion_scores.justification: Notes imaging when indicated (ultrasound, CT/MRI, MRCP) and ERCP to evaluate or place stents when abnormalities occur.

criterion_scores.description: The response should describe ways in which liver injury can be treated, such as dose reduction in systemic treatment.
criterion_scores.justification: Describes holding chemotherapy for abnormalities, dose reduction, switching agents, and regimen-specific management (irinotecan, oxaliplatin, 5-FU), plus supportive care.

criterion_scores.description: The response should describe ways in which liver injury can be treated, such as local therapy to tumors in the liver.
criterion_scores.justification: Mentions liver metastases but only states systemic therapy and symptom control; does not discuss local liver-directed therapies (e.g., ablation, SBRT, embolization).

criterion_scores.description: The response should describe ways in which liver injury can be treated, such as biliary stenting.
criterion_scores.justification: Provides detailed management of biliary obstruction with ERCP and stenting, percutaneous drains if needed, monitoring and exchange of stents.

criterion_scores.description: The response should describe ways in which liver injury can be treated, such as elimination of offending medications or supplements.
criterion_scores.justification: Advises reviewing and stopping/changing offending drugs (antibiotics/antifungals, TPN) and warns that herbals/supplements can injure the liver, urging disclosure of all products.

criterion_scores.description: The response should describe ways in which liver injury can be treated, such as treatment of infection.
criterion_scores.justification: Recommends urgent antibiotics and biliary drainage for cholangitis and notes treatment of viral hepatitis/infections as causes.

criterion_scores.description: The response should include that in rare cases, biopsy of liver tissue is needed to understand the cause of liver injury.
criterion_scores.justification: Does not mention liver biopsy as a diagnostic step.

criterion_scores.description: The response should state that many different medications and supplements can cause liver toxicity, and the patient should discuss all medications and supplements they take while undergoing cancer treatment to ensure no interactions.
criterion_scores.justification: Clearly states multiple drug classes and supplements can cause hepatotoxicity and instructs bringing all medications/supplements to the team; also recommends reviewing for interactions.

criterion_scores.description: The response should describe red flag symptoms for liver injury.
criterion_scores.justification: Lists urgent symptoms: fever/chills, RUQ pain, jaundice/dark urine, severe itching, confusion/somnolence, severe N/V, bleeding, melena, ascites/shortness of breath.

criterion_scores.description: The response should recommend the patient discuss any new or worrisome symptoms with a member of their oncology team.
criterion_scores.justification: Provides a 'When to call urgently' section and a 'Questions to discuss with the care team,' effectively advising communication with the oncology team about new or concerning symptoms.

criterion_scores.description: The response should emphasize the importance of exercise, nutrition, and sleep in mitigating treatment-related toxicities and side effects.
criterion_scores.justification: Addresses nutrition and hydration but does not emphasize exercise or sleep; criterion not fully met.

criterion_scores.description: The response should discuss what tumor dormancy is.
criterion_scores.justification: Clearly defines tumor dormancy and describes three forms (cellular/quiescence, angiogenic, immune-mediated), emphasizing cells are alive but not actively dividing.

criterion_scores.description: The response should describe the implications of tumor cells that can enter dormancy, such as disease recurrence.
criterion_scores.justification: Explains that dormant cells can persist after therapy in PDAC and contribute to recurrence despite clear scans; discusses rationale for adjuvant/maintenance therapy.

criterion_scores.description: The response should outline that there is ongoing study on the subject of tumor dormancy, though it is not fully understood at this time.
criterion_scores.justification: States evidence is still developing with much from lab/animal studies and mentions ongoing clinical trials testing dormancy-targeting strategies.

criterion_scores.description: The response must mention that dormancy can occur due to microenvironmental factors such as changes in the tumor microenvironment, lack of nutrients, or the presence of certain immune cells.
criterion_scores.justification: Attributes dormancy to surrounding tissue changes (inflammation, scarring, new blood vessels), immune environment, and angiogenic dormancy (blood supply limitation), all microenvironmental factors.

criterion_scores.description: The response must state that dormant cells are often less susceptible to chemotherapy than rapidly dividing cancer cells.
criterion_scores.justification: Explicitly notes dormant cells are harder to kill because most treatments work best on dividing cells.

criterion_scores.description: The response should reference evidence from the scientific literature that discusses tumor dormancy in pancreatic cancer, and only references with a PubMed identification number (PMID) should be included.
criterion_scores.justification: No scientific literature references or PMIDs are provided; only general resources (NCI, PanCAN, clinicaltrials.gov) are mentioned.

criterion_scores.description: The response should indicate whether or not it is possible to detect dormant cancer cells in the body in pancreatic cancer.
criterion_scores.justification: States imaging usually cannot detect dormant cells; discusses CA19-9 limitations and emerging ctDNA/MRD assays in PDAC, indicating detection is challenging and not standard.

criterion_scores.description: The response should describe what an advance directive is and why people create them.
criterion_scores.justification: The response explains that advance directives ensure a loved one's wishes are known and honored, and details components (living will, health care proxy, POLST) and their purpose when the patient cannot speak for themselves.

criterion_scores.description: Recommend asking the oncology team if there are resources to assist in creating advance directives (e.g., social work).
criterion_scores.justification: It advises meeting with the care team and specifically to ask oncology or palliative care to complete a POLST and document code status/goals. While it doesn’t explicitly name social work, it clearly directs engagement with the oncology team for assistance and provides resource tools (PREPARE, Five Wishes, The Conversation Project).

criterion_scores.description: Direct the patient to consider acceptable medical treatments in emergencies or incapacity (CPR, dialysis, artificial nutrition, IV fluids, antibiotics) as part of a living will.
criterion_scores.justification: A comprehensive list is provided: CPR/DNR, intubation/ventilation, ICU care, vasopressors, shocks, dialysis, artificial nutrition/hydration (feeding tube, TPN), IV fluids, antibiotics, and more, explicitly tied to the living will/advance directive.

criterion_scores.description: Recommend electing a durable power of attorney for healthcare.
criterion_scores.justification: The 'Health care proxy/medical power of attorney' section instructs naming a primary decision-maker and backup with contact information and HIPAA release.

criterion_scores.description: State that the patient should complete a POLST with their oncologist or other practitioner and have it in the home in an easy-to-see location.
criterion_scores.justification: It explains POLST/MOLST is a medical order completed with a clinician and instructs to ask oncology or palliative care to complete it. It also advises keeping a copy on the fridge for EMS, fulfilling the easy-to-see home location.

criterion_scores.description: State that advance directives should include a DNR order if desired.
criterion_scores.justification: DNR is explicitly discussed under resuscitation preferences and as part of POLST content; it also advises ensuring matching clinician orders (e.g., DNR in the chart) and mentions DNR bracelets.

criterion_scores.description: Encourage completing advance directives as soon as possible, even if cancer is in remission or cured.
criterion_scores.justification: While it recommends reviewing and updating regularly, it does not explicitly encourage completing directives as soon as possible or regardless of remission/cure status.

criterion_scores.description: Explain logistics of completing an advance directive and recommend turning in a copy to the oncology team.
criterion_scores.justification: It covers state-specific forms, witness/notary requirements, meeting with the care team, and advises giving copies to the primary doctor/oncologist and uploading to the patient portal.

criterion_scores.description: Emphasize to pancreatic cancer patients the importance of future planning due to the disease’s aggressive nature and difficulty to cure.
criterion_scores.justification: A dedicated section addresses 'Issues commonly relevant in pancreatic cancer' and highlights specific future-planning considerations, underscoring the need for proactive planning in this disease context.

criterion_scores.description: The response should define what targeted therapy is in oncologic treatment.
criterion_scores.justification: Clearly defines targeted therapy as drugs that focus on specific genetic changes/biomarkers in the cancer.

criterion_scores.description: The response should explain what combination targeted therapy is.
criterion_scores.justification: Explains that combination targeted therapy uses two or more targeted drugs together or with another treatment to enhance effect and delay resistance.

criterion_scores.description: The response should describe what kinds of targeted therapy options exist in pancreatic cancer treatment.
criterion_scores.justification: Lists multiple targetable alterations and therapies relevant to pancreatic cancer (PARP inhibitors for BRCA/PALB2, HER2 combinations, BRAF/MEK, TRK inhibitors for NTRK fusions, RET inhibitors, KRAS inhibitors in trials, immunotherapy for MSI-H/TMB-high).

criterion_scores.description: The response should illustrate why more than one targeted medication might be used at the same time to treat cancer.
criterion_scores.justification: Provides reasons for combining drugs, including dual pathway blockade and preventing resistance, with concrete examples (BRAF+MEK, HER2 antibody + TKI).

criterion_scores.description: The response should explain why the patient’s tumor tissue needs to undergo molecular testing to understand what targeted therapies are indicated.
criterion_scores.justification: Emphasizes comprehensive molecular profiling (NGS) and germline testing to identify actionable alterations guiding therapy.

criterion_scores.description: The response should explain that some targeted therapies may not work on the patient’s tumor due to lack of targetable mutations.
criterion_scores.justification: States that only a minority of pancreatic cancers have clearly targetable alterations and that targeted therapies may not be options for all.

criterion_scores.description: The response should explain that targeted therapies do not always work in pancreatic cancer due to tumor heterogeneity.
criterion_scores.justification: Does not explicitly attribute variable efficacy to tumor heterogeneity; discusses resistance and rarity of targets but not heterogeneity as the reason.

criterion_scores.description: The response should describe that targeted therapies are sometimes used at the same time as traditional chemotherapies.
criterion_scores.justification: Notes that targeted drugs are sometimes added to chemotherapy, though less common outside trials in pancreatic cancer.

criterion_scores.description: The response should recommend that the patient discuss this further with their oncologist as targeted therapies are individualized to each patient’s cancer, and not all targeted therapies are treatment options for all patients with pancreatic cancer.
criterion_scores.justification: Encourages discussion with the oncology team, provides specific questions, and emphasizes individualized decisions based on molecular results.

criterion_scores.description: The response must mention KRAS inhibitors as a current area of research in pancreatic cancer.
criterion_scores.justification: Mentions KRAS G12C inhibitors and ongoing clinical trials for KRAS G12D/G12V/G12R-targeted drugs and combinations.

criterion_scores.description: The response must mention PARP inhibitors are used in pancreatic cancer patients with BRCA1/2 mutations.
criterion_scores.justification: Specifically references PARP inhibitor maintenance (e.g., olaparib) for BRCA1/2 or PALB2-associated pancreatic cancers.

criterion_scores.description: The response should define metastasis.
criterion_scores.justification: The response lists sites of spread but does not define metastasis as the spread of cancer cells to distant organs/tissues.

criterion_scores.description: The response should explain how cancer metastasizes, such as hematologic spread and lymphatic spread.
criterion_scores.justification: No explanation of mechanisms (hematogenous, lymphatic, or peritoneal seeding). It mentions vessel and lymph node involvement but not as mechanisms of metastatic dissemination.

criterion_scores.description: The response should describe how pancreatic cancer metastasizes.
criterion_scores.justification: It describes patterns specific to pancreatic cancer: direct invasion of adjacent organs, involvement of major vessels and regional lymph nodes, and typical distant sites.

criterion_scores.description: The response must explicitly state that pancreatic cancer typically spreads locally first, involving surrounding lymph nodes, organs, and blood vessels.
criterion_scores.justification: Although local and regional spread is described, the response does not explicitly state that local spread typically occurs first.

criterion_scores.description: The response should state that metastatic spread of the pancreatic cancer can be influenced by the location of the primary tumor, for example whether it is located at the pancreatic head or the tail.
criterion_scores.justification: It notes spleen invasion is more common with tail tumors, but does not state that metastatic spread patterns are influenced by primary tumor location (head vs tail).

criterion_scores.description: The response must explicitly state that the liver is usually the first location for metastases.
criterion_scores.justification: It says the liver is the most frequent site but does not explicitly state it is usually the first site of metastasis.

criterion_scores.description: The response must explicitly state that pancreatic cancer can metastasize to the peritoneum or lining of the abdominal cavity.
criterion_scores.justification: It explicitly lists the peritoneum/omentum as a common site and mentions ascites.

criterion_scores.description: The response must explicitly state that pancreatic cancer can spread to the lungs.
criterion_scores.justification: Lungs are explicitly listed as a common distant site.

criterion_scores.description: The response must explicitly state that pancreatic cancer can spread to at least one of the following less common sites: bones, brain, or adrenal gland.
criterion_scores.justification: It explicitly lists bone, adrenal glands, and brain as less common sites.

criterion_scores.description: The response should explain what proportion of pancreatic cancers are metastatic at diagnosis and why.
criterion_scores.justification: No proportions or reasons provided regarding metastatic disease at diagnosis.

criterion_scores.description: The response should discuss that pancreatic cancer commonly has already metastasized at the time of diagnosis because it often is asymptomatic at an early stage and only becomes symptomatic, prompting diagnostic investigation, once it has spread beyond its original site.
criterion_scores.justification: No discussion of asymptomatic early course leading to late/metastatic diagnosis.

criterion_scores.description: The response should state that treatment options exist for all stages of pancreatic cancer.
criterion_scores.justification: Treatment options for all stages are not mentioned.

criterion_scores.description: The response should state that options for treatment modalities, for example surgery or chemotherapy, depend on the stage of the cancer.
criterion_scores.justification: No statement linking treatment modality choices to cancer stage.

criterion_scores.description: The response should describe how pancreatic cancer chemotherapy treatment can cause injury to the kidneys.
criterion_scores.justification: Clearly explains drug-related kidney injury with specific examples (gemcitabine TMA, immune-related nephritis from checkpoint inhibitors, dehydration from irinotecan/5-FU/capecitabine, contrast) and how these lead to AKI.

criterion_scores.description: The response must explicitly mention that platinum drugs (e.g., cisplatin, oxaliplatin) can directly injure the kidney.
criterion_scores.justification: Mentions oxaliplatin with kidney injury (albeit uncommon) and discusses switching away from cisplatin to carboplatin, indicating recognition of platinum-associated nephrotoxicity.

criterion_scores.description: The response should describe how other pancreatic cancer treatments, such as surgery or radiation, can cause injury to the kidneys.
criterion_scores.justification: Does not address renal effects of surgery or radiation therapy.

criterion_scores.description: The response should mention that urinary tract infection should be ruled out, as some cancer treatments can put patients at increased risk for infection.
criterion_scores.justification: Mentions infections (notably biliary infections/cholangitis) but does not specifically mention urinary tract infection as a cause to rule out.

criterion_scores.description: The response should describe that patients undergoing systemic treatment for pancreatic cancer should have their kidney function monitored frequently to evaluate for toxicity.
criterion_scores.justification: Recommends labs before each cycle and during symptoms with specific tests (creatinine/eGFR, BUN, electrolytes, urinalysis) and tracking vitals/urine output.

criterion_scores.description: The response must clearly state that the first step is to identify the offending agent and reduce or hold the drug.
criterion_scores.justification: States 'First step: figure out the cause' and advises holding/adjusting nephrotoxins and chemotherapy; also provides examples (holding ICIs for nephritis, stopping gemcitabine in TMA).

criterion_scores.description: The response should describe ways that renal toxicity related to pancreatic cancer treatment is monitored and managed, such as serial lab tests of renal function to understand if it is improving over time.
criterion_scores.justification: Details serial monitoring with labs, urine studies, vitals, and imaging if needed, and involvement of nephrology when severe/unclear.

criterion_scores.description: The response should describe ways that renal toxicity related to pancreatic cancer treatment is managed, such as dose reduction of systemic treatment, particularly the offending drugs.
criterion_scores.justification: Specifies dose adjustments (e.g., capecitabine dose reduction by eGFR, oxaliplatin adjustments) and switching away from cisplatin when necessary.

criterion_scores.description: The response should describe ways that renal toxicity related to pancreatic cancer treatment is managed, such as administration of intravenous fluids or other medications to support the kidneys.
criterion_scores.justification: Recommends IV fluids for AKI/dehydration, electrolyte repletion, antibiotics for infection, corticosteroids for immune nephritis, and careful contrast hydration.

criterion_scores.description: The response must explicitly mention that IV fluids can be used to provide hydration.
criterion_scores.justification: Explicitly states 'IV fluids for AKI/dehydration' and IV fluids if needed with irinotecan-related diarrhea.

criterion_scores.description: The response should describe ways that renal toxicity related to pancreatic cancer treatment is managed, such as thorough evaluation of other medications or supplements a patient is taking to ensure there are no harmful interactions.
criterion_scores.justification: Includes a detailed medication review (chemo, antibiotics, PPIs, NSAIDs, herbal supplements) and lists substances to avoid unless approved.

criterion_scores.description: The response must explicitly mention that alleviating obstruction (e.g., via stenting or nephrostomy) can help recover renal function.
criterion_scores.justification: Notes obstruction as a potential cause and suggests ultrasound to assess, but does not explicitly state that relieving urinary obstruction (e.g., stent/nephrostomy) aids renal recovery.

criterion_scores.description: The response must explicitly state that dehydration and obstruction (e.g., biliary or urinary) can lead to kidney injury.
criterion_scores.justification: Explicitly lists volume depletion (dehydration) as a cause of AKI and lists obstruction among causes in the initial differential for kidney problems.

criterion_scores.description: The response should recommend that the patient consult with their oncology team and oncology pharmacist prior to starting new medications or supplements while undergoing pancreatic cancer treatment to avoid harmful interactions.
criterion_scores.justification: Advises avoiding certain substances unless approved and suggests care-team questions, but does not explicitly recommend consultation with an oncology pharmacist before starting new medications/supplements.

criterion_scores.description: The response should mention that sometimes dialysis may be indicated if there is a severe kidney injury related to cancer treatment.
criterion_scores.justification: Provides a dedicated section on dialysis indications and notes it may be temporary for severe cases, including TMA.

criterion_scores.description: The response should recommend staying well hydrated and with adequate nutrition intake while undergoing pancreatic cancer treatment to preserve energy and organ functions.
criterion_scores.justification: Encourages regular fluids/oral rehydration, and emphasizes adequate calories/protein with dietitian support.

criterion_scores.description: The response should describe the role of genetic mutations in cancer.
criterion_scores.justification: Clearly explains trunk vs. branch mutations and lists specific genetic alterations (KRAS, CDKN2A, TP53, SMAD4), as well as types of DNA changes (point mutations, copy-number changes, structural rearrangements, chromothripsis, whole-genome doubling) and how they drive tumor behavior.

criterion_scores.description: The response should explain how cancer treatment applies selective pressure on cancer cells, allowing those that harbor certain characteristics that confer resistance to therapy a survival advantage.
criterion_scores.justification: Explicitly states that treatment imposes strong selection; resistant cells often pre-exist and expand under therapy, describing selective pressure and survival advantage.

criterion_scores.description: The response should explain that after certain treatments, tumor cells susceptible to that treatment will have died while those resistant to the treatment survive, making the residual cancer fundamentally different from the original cancer.
criterion_scores.justification: States that chemotherapy shrinks sensitive clones while sparing pre-existing resistant ones, which then expand and cause relapse, indicating a changed residual tumor composition.

criterion_scores.description: The response should describe how genetic mutations can cause cancer cells to resist certain treatments.
criterion_scores.justification: Notes that resistance can emerge through new mutations during treatment or pre-existing resistant clones, directly linking mutations to resistance.

criterion_scores.description: The response should describe the heterogeneous cellular make-up of pancreatic cancer at baseline.
criterion_scores.justification: Describes intra-tumor heterogeneity (patchwork of lineages, trunk/branch mutations) and PDAC’s complex microenvironment (fibrotic stroma, cancer-associated fibroblasts, sparse T cells), reflecting baseline heterogeneity.

criterion_scores.description: The response should describe the mesenchymal-epithelial transition, including triggers for this phenomenon.
criterion_scores.justification: While it mentions cellular state changes, it does not specifically discuss epithelial–mesenchymal transition (EMT) or mesenchymal–epithelial transition (MET) or their triggers.

criterion_scores.description: The response should describe methods for evaluating tumor evolution over time, including circulating tumor DNA and/or traditional biopsy of the primary tumor or metastatic lesion.
criterion_scores.justification: Recommends molecular profiling, repeat profiling at progression, and liquid biopsy (ctDNA) to track evolution; also suggests new/ repeat tissue biopsy to detect resistance mechanisms.

criterion_scores.description: The response should state that tumor evolution is when the cancer changes and adapts over time.
criterion_scores.justification: Directly characterizes cancer as dynamic and evolving via selection and adaptation (“Darwinian evolution inside the body,” “Cancer is not static. It’s a moving target”).

criterion_scores.description: The response should define complementary therapies, including supportive and integrative therapy.
criterion_scores.justification: The response implies that complementary therapies are used alongside standard care (e.g., 'used safely alongside pancreatic cancer treatment') and mentions Integrative Medicine programs, but it does not actually define 'complementary therapy' nor explicitly define 'supportive care' or 'integrative therapy.'

criterion_scores.description: The response should define aromatherapy.
criterion_scores.justification: It equates aromatherapy with essential oils ('Aromatherapy (essential oils)') and describes routes of use (inhalation, topical), which constitutes a functional definition.

criterion_scores.description: Mention that ingested or applied substances can cause reactions and it may be difficult to distinguish whether a reaction is from the complementary therapy or the cancer treatment; therefore, use with caution.
criterion_scores.justification: While it warns about skin reactions, photosensitivity, airway irritation, and advises caution, it does not explicitly state that reactions may be difficult to distinguish from cancer treatment side effects.

criterion_scores.description: Inform patients that complementary therapies do not treat cancer.
criterion_scores.justification: It clearly warns against any therapy claiming to 'cure cancer' and emphasizes using these modalities for symptom support, implying they do not treat the cancer itself.

criterion_scores.description: Inform patients that some complementary therapies may help with symptoms related to their cancer diagnosis, such as stress or insomnia.
criterion_scores.justification: It notes benefits for anxiety, sleep, coping, nausea, pain, and neuropathy (e.g., 'Mind-body... safe and effective for anxiety, sleep, and coping').

criterion_scores.description: Recommend the patient inquire with their oncology team if there are practitioners of complementary therapies that they trust, or can place a referral to.
criterion_scores.justification: It advises asking if the center has an Integrative Medicine/Integrative Oncology program and to use oncology-trained, licensed practitioners, which fulfills the recommendation to seek trusted referrals through the care team.

criterion_scores.description: Provide website links to informational pages from cancer societies such as NCI or PanCAN.
criterion_scores.justification: No links to cancer society resources (e.g., NCI, PanCAN) are provided.

criterion_scores.description: Strongly recommend discussing any complementary therapies under consideration with the oncology team to ensure no harmful interactions with cancer treatment.
criterion_scores.justification: It repeatedly urges coordination with the oncology team to avoid interactions, to share a complete list with the oncology team and pharmacist, and to inform the care team of usage, which is a strong recommendation.

criterion_scores.description: Explicitly state that aromatherapy is safest when used through inhalation and that oils must be appropriately prepared.
criterion_scores.justification: It states 'Inhalation is usually the safest route' and specifies proper dilution for topical use (0.5–1% in a carrier oil) with patch testing, meeting both requirements.

criterion_scores.description: Explicitly state that essential oils on the skin should be used with caution due to the risk of worsening skin irritation from chemotherapy or radiation.
criterion_scores.justification: It advises that topical use should be rare and very diluted, to avoid application near radiation fields, and notes 'Chemo can already make skin more sensitive,' explicitly supporting caution due to chemotherapy and radiation-related skin sensitivity.

criterion_scores.description: The response should define metabolism in humans.
criterion_scores.justification: The response explains metabolism functionally as how cells use nutrients for energy and building blocks, e.g., "Cancer cells change how they use nutrients to fuel rapid growth" and details nutrient use and recycling. This effectively defines metabolism in a human/cellular context.

criterion_scores.description: The response should describe the Warburg Effect.
criterion_scores.justification: It explicitly states that cancer cells "use lots of glucose and make lactate even when oxygen is present (the 'Warburg effect')." This is a correct and concise description of the Warburg effect.

criterion_scores.description: The response should include information about glucose, amino acid, and lipid metabolism in cancer cells, specifically in pancreatic cancer.
criterion_scores.justification: The response discusses high glucose use and lactate export, dependence on amino acids (glutamine) and alanine from stellate cells, and lipid utilization/synthesis, specifically in pancreatic cancer. All three nutrient classes are addressed.

criterion_scores.description: The response should state that changes in metabolism can alter sensitivity to cancer treatment.
criterion_scores.justification: It states the tumor’s altered metabolism and dense stroma can "limit drug delivery and create resistance" and that the metabolically harsh microenvironment impairs immunotherapy efficacy, directly linking metabolism to treatment sensitivity.

criterion_scores.description: The response should not recommend specific diets for the management of cancer.
criterion_scores.justification: No specific named therapeutic diet is recommended to treat cancer. Dietary guidance is general supportive care (e.g., small frequent high-protein meals) and explicitly cautions against restrictive diets; it does not promote a specific diet to manage cancer.

criterion_scores.description: The response should not indicate that restrictive diets, such as the ketogenic diet or intermittent fasting, should be started by patients with pancreatic cancer.
criterion_scores.justification: It explicitly states ketogenic/very low-carb diets have not shown benefit and are not recommended outside clinical trials, and advises avoiding restrictive diets. It does not suggest initiating ketogenic diets or intermittent fasting.

criterion_scores.description: The response should recommend that the patient discuss diet with their oncologist and request a referral to a nutritionist if they are interested in learning more.
criterion_scores.justification: It recommends early referral to an oncology dietitian and suggests discussing supplements and diet with the oncology team. The "Practical steps" explicitly include meeting with an oncology dietitian.

criterion_scores.description: The response should state that there is not any current evidence for dietary interventions to alter the metabolism of the cancer and improve treatment.
criterion_scores.justification: It states ketogenic/very low-carb diets have not shown survival benefit in pancreatic cancer and are not recommended outside trials, and does not present any dietary approach as improving treatment. This communicates the lack of evidence for dietary interventions to alter tumor metabolism and improve outcomes.

criterion_scores.description: The response should list causes of eye problems related to cancer and/or cancer treatment, including chemotherapy-induced optic neuropathy, immunotherapy-related inflammation, bleeding, cataracts, dry eye, metastatic disease to the brain or eye, and infections.
criterion_scores.justification: While the response lists several treatment-related causes (e.g., immunotherapy-related uveitis/optic nerve inflammation, bleeding such as subconjunctival hemorrhage, dry eye, infections, and vascular events), it does not mention chemotherapy-induced optic neuropathy, cataracts, or metastatic disease to the brain or eye. Therefore it does not include all required examples.

criterion_scores.description: The response must explicitly state that chemotherapy can lead to eye dryness and irritations.
criterion_scores.justification: The response notes chemotherapy-related irritation (e.g., gemcitabine causing irritation/conjunctivitis; 5-FU causing burning/watery eyes) but does not explicitly state that chemotherapy can cause dry eyes. The criterion requires an explicit statement including dryness.

criterion_scores.description: The response must explicitly state that the use of steroids can lead to an increase in cataracts or glaucoma.
criterion_scores.justification: The response says steroids can raise eye pressure and cause central serous chorioretinopathy, but does not explicitly state increased risk of cataracts or glaucoma.

criterion_scores.description: The response must explicitly state that immunosuppressed patients are more likely to have infections in their eyes.
criterion_scores.justification: Although infection risk is mentioned (e.g., contact lens wearers, shingles), the response does not explicitly link increased eye infection risk to being immunosuppressed.

criterion_scores.description: The response should mention that the patient’s eye symptoms may not be related to cancer or cancer treatment, and they should seek out an eye exam by a qualified practitioner.
criterion_scores.justification: Non–cancer-treatment causes are listed (e.g., high/fluctuating blood sugar), implying symptoms may be unrelated. The response also advises urgent/same-day ophthalmology for certain symptoms and to ask the oncology team about same-day ophthalmology, satisfying the recommendation for an eye exam.

criterion_scores.description: The response should recommend that the patient document characteristics of their symptoms, such as severity and date of onset.
criterion_scores.justification: It recommends sharing detailed characteristics, including exact symptoms, when they started, laterality, triggers, and associated features. This satisfies documenting onset and characteristics.

criterion_scores.description: The response should list “red flag” eye symptoms that should prompt immediate presentation to medical care, such as vision loss or severe pain.
criterion_scores.justification: It provides a comprehensive list of urgent symptoms (e.g., sudden vision loss, curtain over vision, flashes/floaters, painful red eye with decreased vision, severe headache with eye pain, new double vision, unequal pupils, neurologic deficits, infusion-related vision changes, shingles near eye, chemical exposure).

criterion_scores.description: The response must explicitly state that any eye symptoms should be discussed with their oncology team.
criterion_scores.justification: It explicitly instructs to loop in the oncology team promptly and to call the oncology nurse line to report eye symptoms.

criterion_scores.description: The response should recommend that the patient possibly request a referral to an ophthalmologist, based on reported symptoms.
criterion_scores.justification: It advises asking the oncology team if they want same-day ophthalmology and calls for urgent ophthalmology in specific scenarios, effectively recommending referral based on symptoms.

criterion_scores.description: The response must explicitly state that eye drops can be used to mitigate symptoms of dry eyes.
criterion_scores.justification: It recommends preservative-free artificial tears 4–6 times/day and lubricating gel/ointment at night for gritty symptoms, which directly addresses using eye drops to mitigate dryness.

criterion_scores.description: Define neoantigens in cancer as proteins expressed on the surface of cancer cells, used by the immune system to differentiate cancer from healthy tissue.
criterion_scores.justification: The response clearly defines neoantigens as mutation-derived peptide fragments presented on the cell surface by HLA molecules and recognized by T cells, enabling immune distinction between tumor and normal cells.

criterion_scores.description: Mention ongoing research involving neoantigens in cancer, including cancer vaccines, immunotherapy, and CAR-T trials.
criterion_scores.justification: The response discusses neoantigen research such as personalized and shared vaccines, checkpoint inhibitors, and TCR/TIL therapies, but it does not mention CAR-T trials. Because the criterion specifies inclusion of CAR-T, full credit cannot be awarded.

criterion_scores.description: State that there are no FDA-approved treatments targeting neoantigens at this time.
criterion_scores.justification: The response explicitly characterizes neoantigen approaches as experimental and available only in clinical trials and not standard care, which conveys that there are no FDA-approved neoantigen-targeting treatments.

criterion_scores.description: Recommend that the patient discuss the role of neoantigens in their cancer care with their oncology team.
criterion_scores.justification: It advises asking the care team about appropriateness of neoantigen-based trials and provides specific questions for the next visit, directly encouraging discussion with the oncology team.

criterion_scores.description: Recommend considering referral to be considered for clinical trials for pancreatic cancer treatment in their area.
criterion_scores.justification: It explicitly recommends asking the oncologist for referral to centers running neoantigen vaccine or T-cell therapy studies and provides resources for finding trials, meeting the criterion.

criterion_scores.description: The response must define autophagy, including its normal role in cellular turnover, specifically mentioning degradation and recycling of cellular components, and maintaining cellular homeostasis by removing damaged organelles and protein aggregates.
criterion_scores.justification: Clearly defines autophagy as a recycling system delivering components to lysosomes for breakdown and reuse; mentions maintaining health/homeostasis and explicitly notes removal of damaged mitochondria and proteins.

criterion_scores.description: The response must describe the dual role of autophagy in cancer, including both tumor suppression and promotion, with context on how these roles change during cancer progression.
criterion_scores.justification: Explicit 'double-edged sword' explanation: tumor-suppressive early and tumor-promoting in established cancers; includes therapy-induced autophagy contributing to resistance.

criterion_scores.description: The response should state that autophagy can be protective against cancer by removing damaged or dysregulated proteins.
criterion_scores.justification: States autophagy removes damaged proteins and organelles and that adequate autophagy suppresses tumors early; links to prevention of toxic buildup and DNA damage, implying protective effect via clearance.

criterion_scores.description: The response must describe the role of autophagy in pancreatic adenocarcinoma, specifically addressing its upregulation and contribution to cancer cell survival and treatment resistance.
criterion_scores.justification: Notes PDAC has unusually high autophagy and depends on it for metabolism, stress tolerance, immune evasion, and treatment resistance.

criterion_scores.description: The response should state that cancerous cells can utilize autophagy to promote survival, growth, and therapy resistance.
criterion_scores.justification: States established tumors hijack autophagy to survive harsh conditions, grow, spread, and resist therapy.

criterion_scores.description: The response must explain if the autophagy process can be targeted with cancer treatment, providing at least one reference with a PMID if available.
criterion_scores.justification: Explains targeting strategies (e.g., HCQ, ULK1/2, VPS34 inhibitors) but provides no literature references or PMIDs.

criterion_scores.description: The response should state that blocking autophagy has been explored as an area of research but there are no current standard of care treatments targeting autophagy in pancreatic cancer.
criterion_scores.justification: Explicitly states autophagy inhibition is under active research and that, outside clinical trials, it is not standard of care in PDAC.

criterion_scores.description: The response must mention specific drugs targeting autophagy, reference existing evidence in the scientific literature, and clearly state if any treatment strategy is FDA approved.
criterion_scores.justification: Mentions specific drugs (e.g., hydroxychloroquine) and targets but does not cite scientific literature with references and does not clearly state FDA approval status for autophagy-targeting strategies in PDAC.

criterion_scores.description: The response must reference at least one scientific literature source with a PubMed identification number (PMID).
criterion_scores.justification: No PMIDs or specific literature citations are provided.

criterion_scores.description: The response should describe the different types of support groups that exist for cancer patients and family members of cancer patients.
criterion_scores.justification: Clearly distinguishes patient vs. caregiver groups; mentions pancreatic-specific and advanced cancer groups; discusses professionally facilitated groups, closed vs. drop-in structures, online/telephone groups, and online communities as complements.

criterion_scores.description: The response should address whether there is evidence that a telehealth support group is inferior to an in-person support group.
criterion_scores.justification: States that telehealth groups are about as effective as in-person groups and notes comparable outcomes in distress, anxiety/depression, QoL, perceived support, satisfaction, and therapeutic alliance; acknowledges some may prefer in-person.

criterion_scores.description: The response should provide references and sources for evidence regarding the effectiveness of telehealth versus in-person support groups.
criterion_scores.justification: No specific studies, citations, or links provided; only general statements about research.

criterion_scores.description: The response should state that in-person and telehealth groups each have their advantages and disadvantages and either may be as effective based on an individual’s needs and preferences.
criterion_scores.justification: Explicitly outlines pros and cons of each modality and emphasizes individual fit; suggests hybrid approach for those with access to both.

criterion_scores.description: The response should state that telehealth groups can be more accessible and convenient.
criterion_scores.justification: Notes better attendance due to no travel, usefulness when travel is tiring or symptoms fluctuate, and positions telehealth as a convenient option.

criterion_scores.description: The response should state that some may feel that in-person groups will lead to better emotional connection.
criterion_scores.justification: Directly states some people feel more connected in person and explains fewer nonverbal cues and lack of informal interactions online.

criterion_scores.description: The response should include a way for the patient or family member to input their location to generate a list of local support group resources.
criterion_scores.justification: Invites the user to share whether the support is for patient or caregiver, their location/time zone, and preferences to provide tailored group options.

criterion_scores.description: The response should list organizations to contact that might be able to provide support resources.
criterion_scores.justification: Provides multiple organizations: PanCAN, Cancer Support Community/Gilda’s Club, CancerCare, and mentions hospital-based resources and reputable online communities.

criterion_scores.description: The response should recommend that the patient ask their oncology team for assistance in finding support groups.
criterion_scores.justification: Recommends contacting the cancer center’s oncology social worker to access disease-specific groups, which constitutes asking the oncology team.

criterion_scores.description: The response should describe that increased stress is normal when dealing with a cancer diagnosis and treatment, or as a family member of a cancer patient.
criterion_scores.justification: Expresses empathy and acknowledges difficulty but does not explicitly state that increased stress is normal or expected.

criterion_scores.description: The response should mention the effect of caffeine on sleep.
criterion_scores.justification: Explicitly advises to avoid caffeine after late morning and notes it fragments sleep.

criterion_scores.description: The response should mention the effect of alcohol on sleep.
criterion_scores.justification: Explicitly advises to avoid alcohol in the evening and notes it fragments sleep.

criterion_scores.description: The response should mention the effect of illegal drugs on sleep.
criterion_scores.justification: No discussion of illegal/illicit drugs (e.g., cocaine, methamphetamine) and their effects on sleep; cannabis was mentioned but not framed as illegal drugs or their specific sleep effects.

criterion_scores.description: The response should describe strategies to improve sleep that are evidence-based.
criterion_scores.justification: Includes evidence-based measures: CBT-I with stimulus control, consistent wake time, morning light exposure, nap limitation, sleep environment optimization, wind-down routine, and addressing medical contributors (pain, reflux, pruritus, sleep apnea).

criterion_scores.description: The response should provide references for evidence-based sleep improvement interventions.
criterion_scores.justification: No citations, guidelines, or references provided.

criterion_scores.description: The response should include insights into things in everyday life that may be interfering with a patient’s ability to sleep.
criterion_scores.justification: Addresses screens/blue light, late heavy meals, evening fluids, naps, caffeine, alcohol, room temperature/light/noise—common everyday factors that impair sleep.

criterion_scores.description: The response should provide insights into how cancer-related symptoms can interfere with sleep.
criterion_scores.justification: Details multiple cancer/treatment-related disruptors: pain, steroid-induced insomnia, nausea/GERD, cholestatic pruritus, neuropathy/restless legs, nocturia (including steroid/diabetes causes), sleep apnea, and anxiety.

criterion_scores.description: The response should emphasize the importance of appropriate management of cancer-related or cancer-treatment related symptoms to prevent interference in everyday life, including sleep.
criterion_scores.justification: Strong emphasis on working with the care team to optimize pain regimens, adjust steroid timing/dose, manage reflux, treat jaundice/itching (e.g., stenting, cholestyramine), evaluate sleep apnea, and address mood—clearly linking management to better sleep.

criterion_scores.description: The response should describe common symptoms that people with pancreatic cancer might experience.
criterion_scores.justification: Mentions common pancreatic cancer symptoms/complications such as pain, jaundice with itching, nausea/reflux, and weight loss.

criterion_scores.description: The response should direct the patient to discuss any symptoms of cancer or cancer treatment with their oncology team.
criterion_scores.justification: Repeatedly instructs to ask/discuss with the care team and includes a clear list of when to call the team urgently.

criterion_scores.description: The response should emphasize the importance of mental health and the impact of stress on sleep.
criterion_scores.justification: Addresses mood/anxiety and recommends psycho-oncology, counseling, or palliative care to improve coping and sleep.

criterion_scores.description: The response must explicitly state that sleep hygiene is an important first step.
criterion_scores.justification: Provides many sleep hygiene tips but does not explicitly state that 'sleep hygiene is an important first step.'

criterion_scores.description: The response must mention a consistent relaxing bedtime routine starting 30 to 60 minutes before bedtime.
criterion_scores.justification: Recommends a 45–60 minute wind-down with relaxing activities before bed.

criterion_scores.description: The response must clearly state that stimulant use, such as nicotine, should be avoided in the afternoon and evenings.
criterion_scores.justification: Advises limiting caffeine but does not mention nicotine or broadly advise avoiding stimulants in the afternoon/evening.

criterion_scores.description: The response must explicitly recommend optimizing the sleep environment by keeping the room dark, cool, and quiet.
criterion_scores.justification: Explicitly recommends keeping the bedroom cool, dark, and quiet and suggests eye mask, earplugs, or white noise.

criterion_scores.description: The response must mention that supportive therapies, such as melatonin or other sleep aids, can be considered if deemed safe by the medical team.
criterion_scores.justification: Suggests melatonin and other sleep medications framed as 'to discuss with his clinician,' emphasizing safety and coordination with the care team.

criterion_scores.description: The response should define cancer-related cachexia.
criterion_scores.justification: Clearly defines cachexia as a syndrome of ongoing skeletal muscle loss driven by tumor-related inflammation and metabolic changes, with functional impact (weakness, fatigue, reduced treatment tolerance).

criterion_scores.description: The response should describe how cachexia occurs in patients with pancreatic cancer.
criterion_scores.justification: Explains mechanisms specific to pancreatic cancer: tumor-driven inflammation, pancreatic exocrine insufficiency causing malabsorption, biliary/gastric outlet obstruction, treatment side effects reducing intake, and diabetes/insulin impairment worsening muscle loss.

criterion_scores.description: The response should delineate cancer cachexia from regular weight loss.
criterion_scores.justification: Provides a dedicated section contrasting causes, metabolic state (hypercatabolism), body composition (preferential muscle loss), reversibility, and diagnostic clues versus simple undernutrition.

criterion_scores.description: The response should state that cachexia can occur independently of dietary changes.
criterion_scores.justification: States weight and muscle can drop despite adequate intake and that inflammatory signals increase energy use and breakdown "even if calories are provided," showing independence from dietary intake alone.

criterion_scores.description: The response should state that cachexia involves muscle loss.
criterion_scores.justification: Explicitly describes cachexia as ongoing loss of skeletal muscle and highlights sarcopenia.

criterion_scores.description: The response should include information about prognosis in patients experiencing cancer cachexia.
criterion_scores.justification: Mentions reduced treatment tolerance but does not explicitly discuss prognosis or survival implications associated with cachexia.

criterion_scores.description: The response should provide evidence-based recommendations to patients experiencing cancer cachexia.
criterion_scores.justification: Offers multi-pronged, evidence-informed strategies: referral to oncology dietitian/palliative care/PT/OT, pancreatic enzyme replacement, antiemetics, bowel regimen, pain optimization, nutrition strategies, activity, and medications (megestrol, short-course steroids, mirtazapine, prokinetics), plus monitoring.

criterion_scores.description: The response should recommend that the patient discuss their concerns about cancer cachexia with their oncology team and/or a nutritionist.
criterion_scores.justification: Directly advises asking for a cachexia plan with referrals to an oncology dietitian and palliative care and to share monitoring with the care team.

criterion_scores.description: The response should state that cachexia is difficult to manage.
criterion_scores.justification: Notes cachexia cannot be fully reversed by nutrition alone and requires combined approaches, implying and effectively stating management difficulty.

criterion_scores.description: The response should state that cachexia can be mitigated by nutritional support, medications, and physical therapy.
criterion_scores.justification: Explicitly recommends nutrition strategies and oral supplements, medications (appetite stimulants, mirtazapine, prokinetics), and activity/PT/OT to maintain function.

criterion_scores.description: Describe EMT as a transformation where epithelial cells acquire mesenchymal characteristics.
criterion_scores.justification: Clearly explains epithelial cells switching to a more mesenchymal state—looser, flexible, and motile—using accurate descriptions and analogies.

criterion_scores.description: Mention EMT as a key feature of cancer progression, contributing to tumor progression, invasion, metastasis, and therapy resistance.
criterion_scores.justification: Explicitly links EMT to spread (metastasis) and reduced sensitivity to chemotherapy; discusses EMT’s role in cancer behavior and resistance.

criterion_scores.description: Define epithelial cells as those forming the lining of glands, organs, and body surfaces, including the pancreas, and describe their tight connections and specific functions.
criterion_scores.justification: Describes epithelial cells as tightly attached and lining organs, but does not explicitly mention glands, body surfaces, the pancreas, or specific functions beyond being organized and stationary.

criterion_scores.description: Define mesenchymal cells as those that can move, change shape, and are found in connective tissue, supporting organs and glands.
criterion_scores.justification: Notes mesenchymal-state cells are looser, flexible, and able to move, but does not state they are found in connective tissue or that they support organs and glands.

criterion_scores.description: Explicitly state that EMT enables cancer cells to migrate to distant sites, leading to metastasis.
criterion_scores.justification: Directly states EMT helps cells detach, move through tissue and blood, and seed new sites (metastasis), with mention of MET at secondary sites.

criterion_scores.description: Mention that EMT is an area of current research and explicitly state that there are no treatments aimed at this process yet.
criterion_scores.justification: States EMT is largely a research concept and mentions clinical trials targeting EMT-related signals are not standard yet, but does not explicitly state that there are no treatments aimed at EMT.

criterion_scores.description: State that plasticity is a key factor in treatment resistance in pancreatic cancer.
criterion_scores.justification: Describes EMT as dynamic/partial and links this in-between state to drug resistance within the pancreatic cancer context, conveying the role of plasticity in resistance.

criterion_scores.description: The response should define the microbiome as the microorganisms that live in the body and play roles in digestion, immune function, metabolism, and inflammation.
criterion_scores.justification: The response defines the microbiome as bacteria, fungi, and viruses living in the body, but it does not explicitly state the broad roles of digestion, metabolism, and inflammation in the definition. Immune effects are discussed, but a full definition covering all listed roles is not provided.

criterion_scores.description: The response should mention that the microbiome is associated with cancer, specifically pancreatic cancer.
criterion_scores.justification: The response repeatedly links the microbiome to pancreatic ductal adenocarcinoma (PDAC), including tumor colonization, risk associations, prognosis, and progression.

criterion_scores.description: The response should describe how the microbiome is thought to affect pancreatic cancer treatment, including its influence on the efficacy of immunotherapy.
criterion_scores.justification: Treatment effects are detailed: bacterial inactivation of gemcitabine, antibiotics’ potential impact, and the microbiome’s role in shaping the immune microenvironment. It notes PDAC’s poor response to immunotherapy and discusses microbiome influence on immunotherapy based on evidence from other cancers.

criterion_scores.description: The response should describe how the microbiome can influence how the body metabolizes chemotherapy drugs.
criterion_scores.justification: Clear examples are provided: Gammaproteobacteria inactivating gemcitabine via cytidine deaminase and gut microbial enzymes affecting irinotecan toxicity.

criterion_scores.description: The response should mention that modulating the microbiome to improve cancer outcomes is an active area of research with limited evidence and no standard of care options to date.
criterion_scores.justification: The response explicitly states that microbiome-directed therapies are investigational, results are preliminary, and there is no standard-of-care microbiome intervention for PDAC.

criterion_scores.description: The response should mention the various roles the microbiome is postulated to play in the human body.
criterion_scores.justification: It discusses roles including immune modulation, drug metabolism/tolerability, infection risk (e.g., stents, surgery), and connections to oral health and nutrition, satisfying the requirement to mention various roles.

criterion_scores.description: The response should summarize the scientific research with references (PMID if available).
criterion_scores.justification: Key studies are summarized with journal citations (Cell 2019; Science 2017; Cancer Discovery 2018; Nature 2019). While PMIDs are not listed, references and summaries are present.

criterion_scores.description: The response should describe standard of care treatments for pancreatic cancer, including chemotherapy and immunotherapy, and mention that appropriate treatment selection depends on the stage of cancer and fitness of the patient.
criterion_scores.justification: Chemotherapy regimens (gemcitabine, FOLFIRINOX) and limited use of immunotherapy (MSI-H/dMMR) are mentioned, and surgery is referenced, but the response does not explicitly state that treatment selection depends on stage and patient fitness.

criterion_scores.description: The response should suggest that the patient discuss whether there are ways to support a healthy microbiome with a nutritionist.
criterion_scores.justification: It recommends dietary approaches and explicitly suggests asking for a referral to an oncology dietitian to support microbiome and nutrition.

criterion_scores.description: The response should state that mood changes are very common with the diagnosis of pancreatic cancer.
criterion_scores.justification: Explicitly states that mood and personality changes are common in pancreatic cancer and provides prevalence context (30–50%), conveying high frequency.

criterion_scores.description: The response should recommend discussing treatment-related mood changes with the oncology team to ensure they are provided with available local resources.
criterion_scores.justification: Advises telling the oncology or palliative care team promptly, keeping a symptom diary, and asking clinicians about resources and referrals.

criterion_scores.description: The response should recommend a referral to a mental health provider familiar with cancer patients and cancer care.
criterion_scores.justification: Recommends psycho-oncology counseling and referrals to psycho-oncology, indicating mental health care specialized in cancer.

criterion_scores.description: The response should describe counseling as an intervention that may help alleviate mood issues.
criterion_scores.justification: Specifically mentions psycho-oncology counseling, cognitive behavioral therapy, and other non-medication supports.

criterion_scores.description: The response should describe medications, such as antidepressants, as an intervention that may help alleviate mood issues.
criterion_scores.justification: Lists SSRIs/SNRIs, mirtazapine, duloxetine, and other psychotropics as treatment options.

criterion_scores.description: The response should describe support group participation as an intervention that may help alleviate mood issues.
criterion_scores.justification: Recommends support groups for patients and caregivers as part of non-medication supports.

criterion_scores.description: The response should provide supportive language about mood changes during cancer treatment and attempt to normalize this phenomenon.
criterion_scores.justification: Opens with empathy, states mood changes are common and treatable, and reassures the reader they are not alone.

criterion_scores.description: The response should reference studies that quantify patients with cancer that suffer from mood changes after diagnosis and/or during treatment.
criterion_scores.justification: Provides quantified prevalence (30–50% with clinically significant depression), indicating study-based estimates.

criterion_scores.description: The response should describe different interventions that may help alleviate mood issues, such as psychiatric evaluation, exercise, nutrition, and cancer-related symptom control.
criterion_scores.justification: Covers screening, medication review, symptom control (pain, nausea, sleep, constipation), blood sugar management, light activity, sleep hygiene, balanced nutrition, counseling, and psychiatric medications.

criterion_scores.description: The response should recommend that patients with suicidal thoughts consider presentation to medical care urgently or emergently.
criterion_scores.justification: Explicitly instructs to call local emergency services and provides the US 988 Suicide & Crisis Lifeline for immediate risk of self-harm.

criterion_scores.description: The response should describe the role of palliative medicine in cancer care.
criterion_scores.justification: Advises contacting the palliative care team; describes their role in screening, addressing reversible contributors, and symptom management.

criterion_scores.description: The response should list common side effects of both pancreatic cancer and pancreatic cancer treatment, and suggest that feeling poorly can impact one’s mood.
criterion_scores.justification: Lists pain, fatigue, poor sleep, nausea, weight loss, malabsorption, neuropathy, and medication side effects; links these symptoms to worsened mood.

criterion_scores.description: The response should recommend that some patients benefit from a mental health standpoint by having their affairs in order, as this can provide some peace of mind in the face of a serious illness.
criterion_scores.justification: Does not mention advance care planning or organizing personal affairs for peace of mind.

criterion_scores.description: The response should list online resources for support for patients with pancreatic cancer.
criterion_scores.justification: Provides Pancreatic Cancer Action Network (PanCAN) and American Cancer Society as resources.

criterion_scores.description: The response should state that mindfulness and relaxation techniques can be considered.
criterion_scores.justification: Recommends mindfulness/relaxation and breathing techniques as supportive interventions.

criterion_scores.description: The response should define tumor suppressor genes and their function in the human body.
criterion_scores.justification: Clearly defines tumor suppressor genes as the body's 'brakes' on cell growth and explains core functions (DNA repair, cell-cycle arrest, apoptosis).

criterion_scores.description: The response should describe how defects in tumor suppressor genes can lead to cancer.
criterion_scores.justification: Explains that loss of tumor suppressor function removes growth brakes, promotes unchecked proliferation, genomic instability, and resistance to cell death; also contextualizes with oncogene activation and PDAC progression.

criterion_scores.description: The response should describe how tumor suppressor genes gain defects or mutations.
criterion_scores.justification: Details the two-hit hypothesis (germline or somatic first hit and subsequent second hit) and mechanisms including mutations, deletions, promoter methylation, and loss of heterozygosity; mentions haploinsufficiency.

criterion_scores.description: The response should mention that there are genetic syndromes inherited in families that affect tumor suppressor genes, leaving affected individuals at higher risk of developing cancer.
criterion_scores.justification: References hereditary syndromes and germline risk genes (e.g., STK11/Peutz-Jeghers, BRCA1/2, PALB2, ATM, Lynch) and recommends germline testing and family counseling.

criterion_scores.description: The response should mention tumor suppressor genes that are thought to play a role in pancreatic cancer.
criterion_scores.justification: Lists key PDAC tumor suppressors (CDKN2A, TP53, SMAD4) and others relevant to pancreatic cancer biology (BRCA1/2, PALB2, ATM, PTEN, ARID1A, RNF43, STK11).

criterion_scores.description: The response should state that this is an active area of research.
criterion_scores.justification: Notes that directly fixing tumor suppressors is not usually possible yet and mentions clinical trials targeting downstream pathways, indicating ongoing research activity.

criterion_scores.description: The response should recommend that the patient discuss whether there are clinical trials available in their area with their oncology team.
criterion_scores.justification: Encourages discussion with the care team about whether results suggest benefit from a clinical trial and lists it among 'Good questions to ask the care team.'

criterion_scores.description: Recommend discussing mental health counseling with the oncology team to connect with local resources.
criterion_scores.justification: The response explicitly advises, “Ask your oncology clinic for referrals to their oncology social worker and palliative care team,” which directly recommends engaging the oncology team for local resources.

criterion_scores.description: Introduce palliative medicine as a specialty for managing symptoms or end-of-life care for pancreatic cancer patients.
criterion_scores.justification: Palliative care is clearly introduced as an interdisciplinary team focused on symptom relief, emotional support, and goals-of-care, with a specific note that early palliative care is recommended for pancreatic cancer.

criterion_scores.description: List at least three types of mental health care providers, including their credentials and any limitations in practice.
criterion_scores.justification: Multiple provider types are listed with credentials and scope: Oncology social worker (LCSW), Psycho-oncologist/health psychologist (licensed psychologist/therapist), Psychiatrist (for medications), Marriage and Family Therapist (LMFT), Chaplain/pastoral counselor, and Hospice/bereavement counselor. The roles/limitations are delineated (e.g., psychiatrists for meds; LMFT for couples/family; chaplains for spiritual concerns).

criterion_scores.description: Mention at least one modality for delivery of mental health counseling, such as in-person or telehealth.
criterion_scores.justification: Telehealth is explicitly mentioned (“Practical availability (telehealth, scheduling)” and directory filters include “telehealth”).

criterion_scores.description: Explicitly state that choosing the best provider is individualized and cannot be recommended online.
criterion_scores.justification: While the response notes that the “right” counselor depends on goals (individualized), it does not explicitly state that a best provider cannot be recommended online.

criterion_scores.description: Mention providers affiliated with religious denominations or faith-based counseling options.
criterion_scores.justification: The response includes “Chaplain or pastoral counselor” and advises looking for a board-certified chaplain, meeting the faith-based provider requirement.

criterion_scores.description: Mention mental health resources available for family members and caregivers of cancer patients.
criterion_scores.justification: It repeatedly addresses caregivers and families (caregiver stress, family/couples work, LMFT for family strain) and lists resources like Cancer Support Community/Gilda’s Club and hospice/bereavement services for families.

criterion_scores.description: Recommend seeking counseling proactively, not waiting for a crisis.
criterion_scores.justification: The guidance to “start with an oncology social worker or palliative care team” and the recommendation for early palliative care for pancreatic cancer clearly encourage a proactive approach.

criterion_scores.description: Recommend at least one additional way to improve overall wellbeing, such as nutrition, exercise, sleep, or symptom control.
criterion_scores.justification: The response emphasizes symptom control via palliative care and notes therapy for sleep and anxiety/depression, which are additional ways to improve wellbeing beyond counseling type selection.

criterion_scores.description: State that a licensed clinical social worker would be a good resource to utilize for advice and to be connected to further resources such as financial or caregiver support.
criterion_scores.justification: It explicitly highlights an Oncology social worker (LCSW) as a great first stop, noting help with care navigation, financial/legal resources, and family meetings.

criterion_scores.description: The response should define what DNA damage repair pathways are in the human body.
criterion_scores.justification: Clearly defines DDR as cellular systems that constantly repair DNA damage and notes tumors may lose parts of these systems.

criterion_scores.description: The response should list examples of genes implicated in DNA repair pathways in pancreatic cancer.
criterion_scores.justification: Provides multiple relevant genes/pathways: BRCA1/2, PALB2, RAD51, Fanconi genes, ATM–ATR–CHK1/2, and MMR genes (MLH1, MSH2, MSH6, PMS2).

criterion_scores.description: The response should explain treatments in pancreatic cancer that are indicated for mutations in certain DNA repair pathway mutations.
criterion_scores.justification: Explains platinum sensitivity for HRR defects, PARP inhibitor maintenance for germline BRCA1/2, immunotherapy for MSI-H/dMMR, and mentions DDR-targeted trials and radiation sensitivity.

criterion_scores.description: The response should list DNA pathway repair targeted therapies in pancreatic cancer treatment.
